videoTitle: Critical-Care Nurses Recognized for Excellent Patient Care, Outcomes
videoDescription: Critical care nurses at UC San Diego Health provide high-quality treatment and compassionate care in a healing environment. For patients, the treatment, education and support services that nurses provide in the hospital, especially in the ICU, can be deeply impactful and inspiring. Recently, a team in a progressive care unit at our Jacobs Medical Center was recognized by the American Association of Critical-Care Nurses (AACN) with the Beacon Award for Excellence in three areas: patient outcomes, work environment and nursing workforce. For nurses, this award demonstrates a positive and supportive work environment with greater collaboration and higher morale. Learn how patients benefit from an innovative, all-nurse care delivery model with clinical nurse leaders and licensed vocational nurses. Nursing at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/nursing Critical Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/critical-care/ 0:00 Introduction 0:21 Beacon Award signifies care and collaboration 0:44 Reducing risks for infection and injury 1:13 Encouraging professional growth and leadership

videoTitle: Passing the Phone: Nurses Celebrate Successes Across UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Join us in honoring the incredible nurses of UC San Diego Health during Nurses Week. In this special video, our nurses follow the popular "I'm passing the phone to someone who..." trend to showcase the diverse talents, dedication, and compassion of their colleagues. From those who excel in patient care to those who inspire their others, each nurse plays a vital role in leading the way in patient care. Watch as they pass the phone and share heartfelt messages, highlighting what makes each of them extraordinary. UC San Diego Health is a Magnet-accredited hospital system offering a nationally acclaimed team of nurses who deeply care for our patients and their loved ones. https://health.ucsd.edu/for-health-care-professionals/nursing/

videoTitle: Focus on Health: TMS Therapy with Cory Weissman, MD, PhD
videoDescription: Struggling with depression? There’s hope. At UC San Diego Health, we’re advancing the science of mental health. In this episode of "Focus on Health," Cory Weisman, MD, PhD and a psychiatrist at UC San Diego Health, explains how transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) offers new hope for individuals whose depression hasn’t responded to traditional treatments. As one of the region’s most advanced TMS clinics, we combine science with compassionate, personalized care because treating depression means caring for the whole person. More about TMS therapy at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/behavioral-mental-health/depression-treatment/tms/ This video is part of our monthly "Focus on Health" series featuring UC San Diego experts discussing health topics relevant to our community. See more videos in this series: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLp5o_4MxOoYQp05t-pJc8AVrmJGB8MXQH Cory R. Weissman, MD, PhD, is a board-certified psychiatrist who focuses on providing care for patients with treatment-resistant mental illness. More about Dr. Weissman: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1528720661/psychiatry

videoTitle: Men’s Reproductive & Sexual Health with Dr. T. Mike Hsieh, Urologist
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health offers the most comprehensive spectrum of health care for adult men of any age. We prioritize your sexual and reproductive health, which is integral to your physical and emotional well-being. Our experts at the Men's Health Center, like T. Mike Hsieh, MD, urologist, offer the latest treatment options and will personalize a plan for your unique situation. We can accurately diagnose and successfully treat the full spectrum of men's sexual health conditions, including male infertility, Peyronie's disease, erectile dysfunction, low libido, enlarged prostate and or trouble with urination. videoTitle: Day in the Life of a Registered Dietician
videoDescription: What is a day like for a registered dietician? Mallory Callaway, MS, RD, walks us through her routine as a registered dietician for the Step Family Foundation Cardiac Rehab and Wellness Center at UC San Diego Health. Nutrition plays a vital role in heart health, and our dietitians are here to help every step of the way. In our cardiac rehab center dieticians provide nutrition counseling, teach cooking classes, educate patients on heart-healthy choices and provide the support needed for a stronger, healthier future. The Step Family Cardiac Rehabilitation and Wellness Center provides a medically supervised program designed to improve cardiovascular health through exercise, lifestyle changes and stress reduction. https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/cardiac-rehabilitation If you are interested in joining a team that provides world-class care, visit employment.ucsd.edu

videoTitle: Meet Benjamin Massenburg, MD: Plastic and Craniofacial Surgeon
videoDescription: Benjamin Massenburg, MD, is a plastic surgeon who specializes in craniofacial surgery (face, jaw, and skull), including functional and aesthetic nose surgery (rhinoplasty), comprehensive care for cleft lip and palate, facial reconstruction after trauma or cancer, facial feminization, and facial aesthetic surgery. He likes to connect with patients to understand their goals for surgery and make them feel their best. Dr. Massenburg spent a year in medical school as a Paul Farmer Global Surgery Research Associate, splitting the year between Brazil and India. This experience gave him a diverse view of the possibilities plastic surgery can provide for patients. More about Dr. Massenburg: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1497280028/plastic-surgery-surgery More about Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/plastic-reconstructive-surgery/ 00:00 Meet Benjamin Massenburg, MD 00:22 Procedures He Provides 00:42 Helping Patients Feel Their Best 01:05: Global Health Experience 01:24 Why He Specializes in Plastic Surgery

videoTitle: Benefits of Reading to Your Baby
videoDescription: In celebration of National Read Across America Week, parents and medical staff at UC San Diego Health read to our tiniest patients in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) at Jacobs Medical Center in La Jolla. The NICU’s “Wee Reads” program highlights the importance of reading to infants based on the well-studied therapeutic practice. This year, each baby was gifted a new book by neonatal registered nurse, Connie Rodenhiser, RN. The benefit of human connection takes place when a baby hears their parent’s voice, which helps promote brain development and improve parent/baby bonding. By modeling interactive reading, parents can establish this practice with their infants to continue the cumulative benefits of reading years after NICU discharge.⁠ The NICU at Jacobs Medical Center is a Level III, nationally recognized center of excellence, providing the highest level of care available for premature or sick newborns. UC San Diego Health is the only medical center in San Diego to have both a regional NICU and a labor and delivery service in the same facility. Learn more: health.ucsd.edu/care/pregnancy-birth/nicu/

videoTitle: Heart-Healthy Tomato Soup Recipe
videoDescription: Warm up with a heart-healthy soup! ❤️🥣 Watch as Mallory Callaway, registered dietitian at UC San Diego Health, shows us how to assemble this delicious tomato soup recipe packed with nutrient-rich ingredients to support your heart health. Ingredient list: 1 teaspoon olive oil 1 cup diced onion 1 cup diced fennel bulb 2 tablespoons minced garlic 1 tablespoon seasoning mix (granulated garlic & onion, no-salt lemon pepper and paprika) 1 cup no-salt-added tomato sauce 2 cups no-salt-added vegetable broth 1 bay leaf 1/2 cup basil leaves, thinly sliced Try it out and nourish your body with every bite. Bonus—it is vegan and gluten free, too! If you have heart disease or have experienced a cardiac event or surgery, the cardiac rehabilitation and wellness program can help you change your lifestyle and provide you with the tools to stay on your new path. It's part of UC San Diego Health's comprehensive heart care services. UC San Diego Health has the only wellness kitchen in the region. As a part of our Pritikin Intensive cardiac rehabilitation program patients have access to engaging workshops and cooking classes that will teach them how to implement lifestyle changes to improve heart health, shop for and cook heart-healthy meals, lose weight using healthy scientific strategies and make heart-healthy choices when dining out. health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/cardiac-rehabilitation/

videoTitle: Conozca a Benjamín Cruz Rodríguez, MD - Cardiólogo
videoDescription: El Dr. Benjamín Cruz Rodríguez es un cardiólogo certificado que trata a pacientes con insuficiencia cardíaca avanzada, incluidos aquellos que necesitan asistencia circulatoria mecánica o transplante de corazón. Trata miocardiopatías (enfermedades que afectan el músculo cardíaco). El Dr. Cruz busca comprender al paciente en su totalidad y está interesado en la epidemiología de la insuficiencia cardíaca y en encontrar disparidades raciales y étnicas en el acceso a la atención. Como proveedor hispano, puede brindar atención en español a los pacientes que más la necesitan. Además de su práctica en los hospitales de UC San Diego Health, ejerce en clínicas y hospitales afiliados en El Centro y Brawley. Más información sobre el Dr. Cruz: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1457770240/cardiology-transplantation Más información sobre la atención cardíaca en UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular 00:00 Conozca al Dr. Benjamín Cruz Rodríguez 00:10 Enfermedades tratadas 00:38 Enfoque de atención al paciente 00:58 UC San Diego Health y nuestro equipo de cardiología 01:24 Acceso y trabajo con las comunidades hispanas

videoTitle: Meet Benjamín Cruz Rodríguez, MD: Cardiologist
videoDescription: Jose Benjamín Cruz Rodríguez, MD, is a board-certified cardiologist who treats patients with advanced heart failure, including those who need mechanical circulatory support or heart transplantation. He treats cardiomyopathies (diseases that affect the heart muscle). He seeks to understand the whole patient and is interested in the epidemiology of heart failure and finding racial and ethnic disparities in access to care. As a Hispanic provider, he is able to bring Spanish-speaking care to patients who need it most. In addition to his clinical practice at UC San Diego Health, he practices at affiliated clinics and hospitals in El Centro and Brawley. More about Dr. Cruz: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/ More about heart care at UC San Diego Health: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1457770240/cardiology-transplantation 0:00 Meet Jose Benjamin Cruz Rodriguez, MD 0:10 Conditions treated 0:24 Approach to patient care 0:50 Epidemiology of heart failure 1:10 Hope for heart failure patients

videoTitle: Day in The Life of a Physicians Assistant (PA)
videoDescription: Ever wonder what a day in the life of a physician assistant (PA) is like? Samantha Wheeler walks us through her routine as a Physicians Assistant (PA) for the neurosurgery department at UC San Diego Health. Behind every successful neurosurgery, there's a dedicated medical care team working in sync. Physician assistants play a crucial role in our neurosurgery department, providing expert care and support from pre-operative to post-operative stages. From assisting in the operating room to ensuring patients have a smooth recovery, PAs are essential in delivering the highest standard of care. Their advanced practice provider expertise and compassion help our patients navigate complex procedures with confidence. UC San Diego Health is ranked among the top 25 in the nation for neurology & neurosurgery by U.S. News and World Report and delivers the latest in the surgical treatment of brain and spinal disease. Join our world-class team: employment.ucsd.edu

videoTitle: Day in the Life of a Therapy Dog
videoDescription: Ever wonder what a day in the life of a hospital therapy dog is like? ⁠ ⁠ Willow, a golden retriever mix, walks us through her routine as a therapy dog at UC San Diego Health. ⁠ Willow and her handler, Amber Kiefer, frequently visit the Burn Center at UC San Diego Health Medical Center at Hillcrest to bring smiles and comfort to recovering patients. Amber has a strong, personal connection to the Burn Center, 30 years ago her son was admitted as a #patient to the same unit. Amber distinctly remembers when the therapy dogs would visit and the joy and comfort it brought her and her son. ⁠ ⁠ She told herself that one day she would return to UC San Diego Health, but this time with her own therapy dog. They are a part of the Tender Loving Canines (TLC) Therapy Dog Visitation Program and make weekly visits to the hospital. ⁠ ⁠ A big thank you to Willow, Amber and all of our handlers and dogs for bringing love and comfort into our hospitals. 💙 ⁠ https://health.ucsd.edu/support/volunteer/

videoDescription: More about Dr. Liss: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1477733012/urology-cancer Michael Liss, MD, PhD, is a fellowship-trained urologic oncologist specializing in caring for patients with prostate cancer. Dr. Liss offers his patients the full spectrum of treatment options for prostate cancer from monitoring and planning to multimodal treatments, including robotically assisted prostatectomy. videoTitle: Lung Cancer Screening and Treatment with Mark Onaitis, MD, Thoracic Surgeon
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health is improving the prognosis and quality of life for people at risk of or diagnosed with lung cancer. With new screening guidelines, we aim to detect more lung cancers early when tumors can be surgically removed. We also continue to advance treatment options for people with metastatic lung cancer. Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health is San Diego's only National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center, the highest possible rating for a U.S. cancer center. Lung cancer treatment at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/cancer/cancers-we-treat/lung/ Lung cancer screening for current and former smokers between the ages of 50 and 80: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/cancer/screening-diagnosis/lung-cancer-high-risk-program/ Quit Smoking: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/cancer/screening-diagnosis/lung-cancer-high-risk-program/quit-smoking/ This video is part of our monthly "Focus on Health" series featuring UC San Diego experts discussing health topics relevant to our community. videoTitle: Doctor Seeks Out Top Neurosurgeon for Carotid Artery Surgery
videoDescription: When John Carr, MD, endocrinologist in private practice, was diagnosed with a carotid artery dissection in the right side of his neck, he knew he needed a top doctor to care for him. A carotid artery dissection meant Dr. Carr had a severe blockage in an artery that affected blood flow to his brain, which diminished his quality of life significantly and could lead to a stroke. His colleagues recommended Alexander Khalessi, MD, neurosurgeon at UC San Diego Health, where Dr. Carr had reconstruction surgery with stents to restore normal blood flow. More about Carotid Artery Disease Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/stroke-care/carotid-artery-disease/ More about Dr. Khalessi: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11906/neurosurgery-surgery-stroke-care-cancer-neurology 0:00 Introduction 0:25 Dr. Carr Gets Carotid Artery Injury Diagnosis 1:18 Colleagues Recommend Dr. Khalessi 2:21 Emergency Surgery to Reconstruct the Artery 3:18 Grateful for the High Level of Care

videoTitle: Day in Life of a Medical Interpreter
videoDescription: Ever wonder what a day in the life of a medical interpreter is like? Carla Alegre, LSSBB, CHI, walks us through her daily routine as a Spanish medical interpreter at UC San Diego Health. Medical interpreters like Carla play a crucial role in ensuring effective communication between providers and patients who have limited proficiency in the language spoken in the health care setting. Clear communication is part of providing outstanding care for all our patients in our diverse community. We provide translation services in several languages so that you can comfortably discuss your medical needs in your preferred language. This free service is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. If you are interested in joining a team that provides world-class care, visit: employment.ucsd.edu A team at UC San Diego Health provides interpreting services in all the current threshold languages — including ASL — so that you can comfortably discuss your medical needs in your preferred language. This free service is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. To learn more, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/patients/interpreter-language

videoDescription: Vicente Diaz-Gonzalez, MD, primary care physician, explains why you should consider UC San Diego Health as your choice for your care during open enrollment. videoTitle: HPV and Cancer: Get Vaccinated
videoDescription: Protect yourself and your family with HPV (human papillomavirus) immunizations. The HPV vaccine is a safe and effective way to dramatically lower the risk of cancers associated with high-risk strains of the HPV virus, including cervical cancer, head and neck cancer, penile cancer, rectal cancer and vaginal cancer. The HPV vaccine is 90% effective against HPV-associated cancers when given to children ages 9-12. Though less effective in older people, the vaccine may be administered to men and women through age 45. To schedule an HPV vaccine for a child, see pediatrics at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/primary-care/pediatrics/ If you are a UC San Diego student, see student health at UC San Diego: https://studenthealth.ucsd.edu/services/immunizations/hpv-vaccine.html To schedule an HPV vaccine for an adult, see primary care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/primary-care/ Key Moments 00:00 About the HPV Virus 00:42 Preventing HVP-Related Cancer 01:07 Vaccine Recipient at Age 9 01:52 Doses for Children 02:16 HVP Vaccine Effectiveness

videoTitle: Sports Medicine Care with Dr. Catherine M. Robertson, Chief of Sports Medicine
videoDescription: Orthopedic Surgeon Catherine Robertson, MD, explains how sports medicine care at UC San Diego Health helps you get back to your sport as soon as possible. Our team of expert surgeons as well as athletic trainers, physical therapists, nutritionists and psychologists works together to help you meet your goals. More About Sports Medicine at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/sports-medicine/ Catherine M. Robertson, MD, is an orthopedic surgeon and chief of sports medicine at UC San Diego Health. She treats injuries of the shoulder, knee and hip. She uses minimally invasive techniques to restore joint function and treat complex ligament, tendon, cartilage and meniscus injuries. Dr. Robertson is one of the few physicians in Southern California with specialized training in hip arthroscopy (minimally invasive hip surgery) and uses this advanced technique to treat femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) and labral tears of the hip. Dr. Robertson is the head team physician for the San Diego Padres and the lead orthopedic surgeon for the San Diego Seals. She is also a team physician for the UC San Diego Tritons. She was also an associate team physician for the San Diego Chargers. More about Dr. Robertson: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11991/orthopedics-sports-medicine 00:00 Intro 0:19 Care Plans for Surgery and Rehab 0:40 Expert Care for the Padres and You

videoTitle: Multidisciplinary Cancer Clinic for Better Urologic Cancer Care
videoDescription: Whether you're newly diagnosed with urologic cancer or have not yet responded to treatment, our multidisciplinary team approach to your care can improve your outcome and quality of life. The multidisciplinary cancer clinic, located in La Jolla at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Heath, brings some of the region's most experienced oncologists together in one place to deliver convenient and comprehensive care for urologic cancers such as prostate, bladder, kidney and testicular cancer. At this unique clinic, you meet with three specialists — a medical oncologist, urologic surgeon and radiation oncologist — during a single visit. Together, they provide a balanced view of your treatment options. A patient navigator can help you schedule appointments, scans and consults. videoTitle: UC Health Milk Bank: Increasing Donor Milk Access in California
videoDescription: The UC Health Milk Bank has received the Top Honor 2023 Quality Leaders Award from the California Association of Public Hospital and Health Systems, and the California Health Care Safety Net Institute. This prestigious award recognizes an outstanding effort to improve patient care that demonstrates achievement across multiple award categories, including equity, population health, care redesign and innovation. Opened in 2020, the University of California Health (UCH) Milk Bank is the first milk bank located in San Diego. Operated by UC San Diego Health and located in the San Diego Blood Bank, the non-profit facility provides pasteurized, donated human milk critical for feeding sick or premature infants when parents do not have a sufficient milk supply for their baby’s nutritional needs. The nonprofit human milk bank serves families in Southern California and statewide through all six UCH academic health centers. It offers UC San Diego Health patients and the community the opportunity to donate and receive donated human milk when needed for optimal nutrition for newborn babies. Since opening, the UC Health Milk Bank has produced 200,000 ounces of milk and serves 21 hospitals across California. We provided donor milk to 600 families with vulnerable babies in 2022 alone. 0:00 Introduction 0:11 Establishing the Milk Bank 0:43 Support tiniest babies 0:53 Human Milk Better Outcomes 1:25 The Bridge Milk Fund 1:40 Eliminating financial barriers 2:17 Partnering with public hospitals 3:00 Human milk donations by the numbers

videoTitle: Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM) Surgery Improves Student's Quality of Life
videoDescription: Since childhood, Marbella Ramirez suffered from chronic migraines. As she entered her senior year of college, the migraines became more frequent and severe. One night, the pain from a migraine lingered and caused her to miss several days of school. It was at the hospital where she was diagnosed with a ruptured arteriovenous malformation (AVM). AVMs are abnormal connections between an artery and a view located in the brain. Ramirez was referred to UC San Diego Health where she received treatment from Dr. David Santiago-Dieppa and a multi-disciplinary team. The neurological team at UC San Diego Health has extensive experience treating AVMs. (Learn more about AVM care https://health.ucsd.edu/care/stroke-care/avm/) Ramirez recovered from the treatments. She has since graduated and is pursuing a master’s degree. If you’ve been diagnosed with a neurological condition that requires surgery, you need a highly trained and experienced neurosurgeon. The Neurological Institute at UC San Diego Health is a comprehensive care and research center. To learn more, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/neurological/ Dr. David Santiago-Dieppa’s bio: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1083984983/neurosurgery-stroke-care Dr. Alexander A. Khalessi’s bio: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11906/neurosurgery-cancer 00:00 Introduction to Marbella 00:12 Growing up with migraines 01:17 Arteriovenous malformation diagnosis 01:26 AVM treatment plan 02:16 Experts in AVM 02:49 AVM surgery recovery 03:29 Hope for the future

videoTitle: Living Liver Transplant Reignites Patient’s Life
videoDescription: It was an unimaginable gift from Erin Roberts’ brother-in-law that changed her life. “Are you ready to get a new liver?” Henry O’Loughlin asked Erin and her husband, Jake. Erin was diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis in 2018 at age 38, a chronic and progressive condition that destroys bile ducts in the liver and can ultimately cause liver failure. By age 41, Erin’s healthy, active, sports-centered lifestyle morphed into extreme fatigue, sickness and pain. “I felt so sick every single day, and I was usually in bed before my kids were,” Erin said. But Erin’s Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score wasn’t yet high enough to qualify for a deceased liver transplant, even though her quality of life had drastically diminished. That’s when she learned about UC San Diego Health’s “live liver donation program” that gave her newfound hope. Erin’s sister, Shannon O’Loughlin, wasn’t a match for the living liver donation Erin so desperately needed – but it turned out her husband Henry was. UC San Diego Health’s Center for Transplantation is a national hub of clinical expertise and research and is the region’s leader in transplantation. More than 60 percent of Henry’s liver was removed and transplanted to replace Erin’s liver. The liver has a unique capacity to regenerate, and Henry was up for the challenge. “I felt like the right person for the job,” Henry said. “It’s an endless well of joy seeing Erin do so well.” “Just the disbelief that Henry has done this for me – the selflessness of it, I just feel like I have my very own personal superhero,” Erin said. Learn more about liver transplantation at UC San Diego Health here: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/transplant-programs/liver/ 00:00 - Intro video 00:01 - Symptoms of primary biliary colitis 01:17 - living with end-stage liver disease 01:40 - Model for End-Stage Liver Disease score 02:13 - Transplant program at UC San Diego Health 02:36 - Liver transplant consultation 03:30 - Leader in living liver transplant 03:42 - Living liver donor requirements 04:05 - Finding liver donor match 04:16 - Living liver donor explains inspiration 05:38 - Post-surgery living liver transplant 06:00 - Life after donating liver 06:51 - How much liver was removed from donor 07:29 - Life changed since the transplant 07:43 - Liver recipient explains life after transplant

videoTitle: CTEPH Surgery Gives Woman Her Life Back; She Celebrates with Padres Experience
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health joins the San Diego Padres in recognizing Dionne Taylor and bringing awareness to CTEPH, or chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension. Dionne had large blood clots in her lungs, also known as double pulmonary embolisms. She had them dissolved and felt fine for a while. Then, she started noticing an increased shortness of breath in her daily activities and sought diagnosis and treatment at UC San Diego Health. Dionne was diagnosed with CTEPH, high blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries caused by chronic blood clots (thromboembolic), which obstruct the free flow of blood through the lungs. Michael Madani, MD, a cardiothoracic surgeon who specializes in pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (PTE), performed Dionne's surgery. As a fan of the Padres, Dionne and her family were invited to celebrate her recovery at Petco Park where they were treated to lunch at the renovated VIP club. She expressed her gratitude for the medical team at UC San Diego Health, as she credits them for "giving her life back." Our Health Care Home Runs program celebrates UC San Diego Health patients with a special behind-the-scenes experience during a San Diego Padres game at Petco Park. These patients, selected by UC San Diego Health, have shown remarkable strength, courage and resolve to overcome their serious illnesses. UC San Diego Health is the Official Health Care Provider of the San Diego Padres. Beyond delivering exceptional care to some of San Diego's best athletes, the sponsorship enables the collaboration of unique and diverse initiatives to promote healthy living in America's Finest City. We also work together to acknowledge and celebrate our patients. Learn more at https://health.ucsd.edu/padres 0:00 Intro Video 0:18 Meet CTEPH Survivor, Dionne Taylor 0:34 What are CTEPH symptoms? 0:53 CTEPH Diagnosis 1:08 What is PTE surgery? 1:34 Padres VIP Experience

videoTitle: New Weapons Screening System Enhances Security at UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: To ensure a safe space for staff, patients and visitors, the security team at UC San Diego Health has added another layer of protection to facilities by implementing a new, innovative, weapons screening system. Elizabeth Billberry, senior director of security services, provides information about the system. At UC San Diego Health, the well-being and safety of our community is our number one priority. We are committed to providing the highest quality of care in the most secure environment for all individuals entering our hospitals. The new screening system is safe for anyone walking through it and provides accommodations for use by people of all abilities. The system is considered safe for pregnant individuals and those with pacemakers and other implanted medical devices. As the only academic medical center in the region, UC San Diego Health is dedicated to delivering outstanding patient care through commitment to the community, groundbreaking research and inspired teaching. This additional security measure will allow us to continue our mission in a safe and healing environment. For more information about our security screening process, please visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/patients/visitors/ 0:00 Video Intro 0:29 Look at the weapons screening system 1:00 Is the system safe? 1:26 What items are permitted? 1:40 What items are prohibited?

videoTitle: Brain Tumor Survivor Raises Awareness of Care Through Padres Experience
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health joins the San Diego Padres in recognizing Andrew Dower and bringing awareness to his brain tumor experience. Andrew had seizures that were getting closer together over several years. When they became a monthly occurrence, he sought diagnosis and treatment at UC San Diego Health with neurosurgeon Alexander Khalessi, MD, and epilepsy expert Jerry Shih, MD. They determined that the seizures were caused by a tumor in Andrew's right temporal lobe and Dr. Khalessi operated promptly. A longtime fan, Andrew watched the Padres play while recovering from surgery in the intensive care unit at UC San Diego Health. Two months later, he was able to share his enthusiasm for the team with his family at Petco Park. He is grateful for the treatment he received at UC San Diego Health and the chance to live life to the fullest. According to his wife, UC San Diego Health “moved mountains” to provide excellent care. Andrew is also grateful to the San Diego Padres for the opportunity to see the game up close and meet the players. Our Health Care Home Runs program celebrates UC San Diego Health patients with a special behind-the-scenes experience during a San Diego Padres game at Petco Park. These patients, selected by UC San Diego Health, have shown remarkable strength, courage and resolve to overcome their serious illnesses. Beyond delivering exceptional care to some of San Diego's best athletes, the sponsorship enables the collaboration of unique and diverse initiatives to promote healthy living in America's Finest City. We also work together to acknowledge and celebrate our patients. videoDescription: Dr. Sonia Ramamoorthy explains how gastrointestinal disorders affecting the colon and rectum can affect your quality of life. Our colorectal experts are leaders in complex procedures, often using minimally invasive techniques to treat a range of conditions. These include inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), pelvic floor disorders, and colon and rectal cancer. Our team includes world-class surgeons, gastroenterologists and nutritional experts, along with researchers who are working to develop new treatments. She specializes in treating colorectal and anal cancer, IBD and diverticulitis. She also leads the colorectal cancer team at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health. Dr. Ramamoorthy is an expert in open and minimally invasive colorectal surgical procedures and was the first surgeon in San Diego to perform robotically assisted colorectal procedures. She expressed gratitude for her family, close friends and the multi-disciplinary team at UC San Diego Health for their support as she overcame the cancer and is now thriving in life. Our Health Care Home Runs program celebrates UC San Diego Health patients with a special behind-the-scenes experience during a San Diego Padres game at Petco Park. These patients, selected by UC San Diego Health, have shown remarkable strength, courage and resolve to overcome their serious illnesses. UC San Diego Health is the Official Health Care Provider of the San Diego Padres. Beyond delivering exceptional care to some of San Diego's best athletes, the sponsorship enables the collaboration of unique and diverse initiatives to promote healthy living in America's Finest City. We also work together to acknowledge and celebrate our patients. Learn more at https://health.ucsd.edu/padres 0:00 Health Care Home Runs - Cancer 0:17 Meet Hayley Radosevich-Nelson 0:38 Cancer diagnosis 0:57 Treatment at Moores Cancer Center 1:38 Meeting Manny Machado 2:00 Family and friends 2:35 First pitch

videoTitle: It's More Than Just Brain Surgery: Patient Julie Hudash Shares Her Acoustic Neuroma Story
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health treats the most patients with acoustic neuroma (also known as a vestibular schwannoma) and also provides personalized, compassionate care. When Julie Hudash was diagnosed with an acoustic neuroma, she knew it was important to have surgeons with extensive experience and to be "in the hands of people who really cared about me." The care and support she received at UC San Diego Health amazed her. Julie said she didn't just come to UC San Diego Health to get brain surgery, she came to get her life back. And she did. And acoustic neuroma expert Dr. Rick Friedman says his team is committed to helping patients long after their surgery. More about our acoustic neuroma care: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/otolaryngology/areas-expertise/acoustic-neuroma/Pages/default.aspx 0:00 Intro 0:03 Acoustic Neuroma Surgery 0:28 Woman's Hearing Loss Leads to Diagnosis 1:30 Leading Up to Acoustic Neuroma Surgery 2:36 Acoustic Neuroma Team 2:55 Acoustic Neuroma Surgery 3:28 Neurotologist Talks Outcomes, Data 3:50 Post Acoustic Neuroma Surgery Outcome 4:35 Life After Acoustic Neuroma Surgery

videoTitle: Patient Now Helps Others Navigate Their Acoustic Neuroma Journey
videoDescription: When Melissa De La O was diagnosed with an acoustic neuroma, also known as a vestibular schwannoma, she already knew about the condition because her father also had it 35 years prior. She chose UC San Diego Health for treatment because we lead the nation in the number of patients and positive treatment outcomes for this rare benign tumor. We treat the most patients with acoustic neuroma and also provide personalized, multidisciplinary, compassionate care. The surgeons were able to preserve Melissa's hearing, which was her main goal for the middle fossa approach surgery. In fact, Melissa is now the patient navigator for our acoustic neuroma program. She applies her personal experience as she guides patients through the process to achieve the best results possible. More about our acoustic neuroma care: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/otolaryngology/areas-expertise/acoustic-neuroma/Pages/default.aspx 0:00 Intro Video 0:02 Comprehensive Acoustic Neuroma Team 0:15 Consultation 0:40 Patient Navigator's Role 1:00 Patient Shares Family History 1:17 Middle Fossa Approach 1:50 Rehab for Acoustic Neuroma Post-Surgery 2:18 Easing Fears of Acoustic Neuroma Surgery 3:50 UC San Diego Health Cares 4:25 Objective of Acoustic Neuroma Program

videoTitle: Acoustic Neuroma Patient Renee Uribe Explains Why She Chose UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: When Renee Uribe learned she needed surgery for an acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, she chose UC San Diego Health for treatment because we lead the nation in the number of patients and positive treatment outcomes for this rare benign tumor. videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Ranks #1 in San Diego, Makes National Honor Roll
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health has once again ranked # 1 in San Diego! 🏆Placing it among the nation’s best health care providers according to the 2023-2024 U.S. News & World Report “Best Hospitals” survey.  For the first time in the academic medical center’s history, UC San Diego Health was also placed on the 2023-2024 Best Hospitals National Honor Roll, a distinction awarded to only 22 hospitals nationwide that are recognized for outstanding patient care. The annual rankings are designed to assist patients and their doctors in making informed decisions about where to receive care for a variety of health conditions, common elective procedures and complex surgeries. https://health.ucsd.edu/news/press-releases/2023-07-31-uc-san-diego-health-ranks-no-1-in-san-diego-makes-national-honor-roll We're also proud to have these 10 medical and surgical specialties ranked among the nation’s best: Cancer Cardiology, Heart & Vascular Surgery Diabetes & Endocrinology Ear, Nose & Throat Gastroenterology & GI Surgery Geriatrics Neurology & Neurosurgery Obstetrics & Gynecology Pulmonology & Lung Surgery Urology  Only 12% of evaluated hospitals earned a Best Hospitals ranking, a designation given for medical providers that excel at factors such as clinical outcomes, level of nursing care and patient experience. To learn more about the best hospitals rankings, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/usnews

videoTitle: Patient Experience | Improvement Excellence Awards 2023
videoDescription: To learn more about UC San Diego Health, visit https://health.ucsd.edu/ The Medical Offices South pharmacy at UC San Diego Medical Center in Hillcrest utilized surveys to receive direct patient feedback in an effort to improve patient satisfaction at the pharmacy. The goal of this project was to ensure survey responses were easily accessible to the pharmacy team so the patient’s voice was heard and responses could be used to improve processes. With this change, the team has experienced an increase in their Net Promoter Score, a common metric used in customer experience surveys, from 71.2 in April 2022 to 91.9 in November 2022. The nursing team also offered patients a sleep menu to ensure each patient’s personal night time preferences are accommodated, such as closing blinds, dimming the computer monitor, or providing extra bedding. The menu also includes the option to receive a Quiet Kit, which contains a sleep mask, earplugs, and a calming aromatherapy patch. Leaders at UC San Diego Health recently celebrated the institution’s inaugural Improvement Excellence Awards ceremony. The event recognized and celebrated the work of individuals and teams whose improvement projects made a positive impact on UC San Diego Health’s strategic goals and patient care. 0:00 Improvement Excellence Awards 2023 0:18 Adriann Deguzman - Introduction 0:48 Implementing the project 1:30 Improved patient experience

videoTitle: Improving Access: UCSD at Home Program | Improvement Excellence Awards 2023
videoDescription: To learn more about UC San Diego Health, visit https://health.ucsd.edu/ The UCSD at Home – Emergency Department to Home Program ensures that patients leaving the emergency departments at UC San Diego Health receive care that is coordinated by utilizing an interdisciplinary care team approach. videoTitle: Pursuit of Quality: Advanced Certification in Spine Surgery | Improvement Excellence Awards 2023
videoDescription: To learn more about UC San Diego Health, visit https://health.ucsd.edu/ In November 2022, a multidisciplinary team at UC San Diego Health earned The Joint Commission’s Gold Seal of Approval for Advanced Certification in Spine Surgery, which is granted to organizations with data-driven care processes, patient safeguards and demonstrated high-quality patient outcomes with low complication profiles. The team’s main focus in this project was to develop a “Spine Passport” that facilitated better care for spinal surgery patients and developed standard work processes for clinical staff involved in such surgeries. The process involved pre-surgery education with the patient to ensure pertinent information is readily available for the clinical team. Leaders at UC San Diego Health recently celebrated the institution’s inaugural Improvement Excellence Awards ceremony. videoTitle: Mother Joins Therapy Dog Service 30 Years After Son's Stay in Burn Center
videoDescription: Willow and her handler, Amber Kiefer, frequently make visits to the Burn Center at UC San Diego Health Medical Center at Hillcrest to bring smiles and comfort to recovering patients. Amber has a strong, personal connection to the Burn Center, 30 years ago her son was admitted as a patient to the very same unit. Amber distinctly remembers when the therapy dogs would visit and the joy and comfort it brought to both her and her son. ⁠ ⁠ She told herself that one day she would return to UC San Diego Health, but this time with a therapy dog of her own. Her and Willow are a part of the Tender Loving Canines (TLC) Therapy Dog Visitation Program and make weekly visits to the hospital. ⁠ For interested volunteers hoping to take part in the TLC program with their certified therapy dog, the team can be contacted at volsvcs@health.ucsd.edu or visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/giving/volunteer/ 0:00 Therapy dogs back at the hospital 0:13 Meet Amber and Willow 0:39 Ambers personal connection 1:06 Willow helps a patient

videoTitle: Cancer Immunotherapy Trial Individualizes Therapy
videoDescription: Clinical trials at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/clinicaltrials Bernard Thurman has undergone traditional treatments, experimental therapies and surgeries to counter the cancer within him, but nothing has successfully eradicated the disease. As a last-ditch effort to halt growth, Thurman was referred to a personalized cancer therapy trial being developed at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health. The clinical trial, a collaboration between UC San Diego and La Jolla Institute for Immunology researchers, employs an investigational cell therapy that uses a patient’s own immune cells — specifically tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TIL) — to seek and destroy their own unique cancer cells. More information about Cancer Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/cancer/ More information about Immunotherapy at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/cancer/treatments/immunotherapy/ 0:00 Cancer Immunotherapy Trial 0:17 Bernard's journey 1:00 Tumor infiltrating lymphocytes 1:50 How it works 2:28 Individualized therapy

caption: true

videoTitle: Ezra Cohen, MD, Explains Precision Immunotherapy
videoDescription: Ezra Cohen, MD, explains how immunotherapy treatments at UC San Diego Health are personalized to each person’s cancer tumor. Personalized cancer care includes identifying patients who will respond the best to specific approaches, designing therapies for small groups of patients or even individuals, and then carefully monitoring each person's response. In some instances, a vaccine may be tailor-made for a cancer patient. This level of innovation is only offered at UC San Diego Health. Learn more about the immunotherapy treatment at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/immunotherapy/Pages/precision-immunotherapy-clinic.aspx

videoTitle: Academic Medicine with Christopher Kane, MD, Urologist
videoDescription: Christopher Kane, MD, explains how UC San Diego Health, the region's only academic medical center, improves people’s lives and shapes the future of medicine. Academic medical centers (also called academic health centers) are university-based hospital systems that play a unique and valuable role in our nation’s health care system. These include: - Delivering highly specialized care for complex conditions or rare diseases beyond the scope and expertise of community hospitals - Developing new medicines and technologies to prevent and treat disease - Teaching the next generation of physicians and other providers - Serving as a safety net for the at-risk or underrepresented More about academic medicine at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/about-us UC San Diego Health is one of six academic medical centers within the University of California system. More about University of California Health: https://health.universityofcalifornia.edu/ This video is part of our monthly "Focus on Health" series featuring UC San Diego experts discussing various health topics. See more videos in this series: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLp5o_4MxOoYQp05t-pJc8AVrmJGB8MXQH Dr. Kane is the dean of clinical affairs for UC San Diego School of Medicine and chief executive officer of UC San Diego Health Physician Group. More about Dr. Kane: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11850/urology-cancer 0:00 Focus on Health - Academic Medicine 0:10 Christopher J. Kane, MD 0:23 Leading edge medicine 0:45 Guided by science

videoTitle: Facial Nerve Surgeons Give Firefighter His Smile Back
videoDescription: Learn more about the UC San Diego Health facial paralysis treatment: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/otolaryngology/areas-expertise/facial-nerve/Pages/default.aspx Steve Chafe, a firefighter for more than 25 years, is not taking anything in life, including a smile, for granted. Nearly five years ago, after finishing a 72-hour shift, his life changed. He couldn’t quite gather his thoughts; he couldn’t read, and his speech was jumbled. An MRI identified Chafe had a transient ischemic attack. It also found something unexpected: a large tumor the size of a golf ball. Due to the size and position of Chafe’s tumor, delicate facial nerves were impacted, leading to facial drooping and paralysis on the right side of his face. His tumor was removed November 2018, which paved the way for a specialized team at UC San Diego Health to repair the damage the tumor caused and ultimately, get his smile back. More about Dr. Greene: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33213/ent-head-and-neck-%28otolaryngology%29-surgery More about Dr. Nguyen: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11799/ent-head-and-neck-%28otolaryngology%29-surgery 0:00 - Firefighter Steve Chafe 0:18 - MRI reveals something unexpected 0:46 - Removing the tumor 1:13 - Dr. Greene explains Steve's gracilis free muscle transfer 2:16 - Dr. Nguyen highlights the multidisciplinary care at UC San Diego Health 3:11 - Life after surgery for Steve
tags: facial palsy,gracilis,brain tumor,nerve transfer,facial reanimation,surgery,UC San Diego Health,UCSD,UC San Diego,San Diego Hospital,Facial Paralysis Treatment,firefighter,surgeons rescue firefighter,neurosurgery,neurosurgeons,got his smile back,surgery for facial reconstruction,facial reconstruction

videoTitle: Don’t Know CPR? There’s an App for That
videoDescription: Download the app: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/rescue-me-cpr/id6444015471 https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.bmapp.cpr_app Mark Greenberg, MD, an anesthesiologist at UC San Diego Health, and his research team have created the free Rescue Me CPR! app as a tool to help combat the surge of opioid overdoses. The app uses videos, simple instructions and a series of prompts to walk anyone – trained or untrained in CPR – through all the steps necessary to perform basic life support in real-time. To learn more about Rescue Me CPR!, visit: https://www.odrescueme.com/ 0:00 Introduction 0:10 Rescue Me CPR app 0:22 How it works 0:43 Dr. Mark Greenberg 0:51 App demonstration

videoTitle: Saline Nasal Rinse How To
videoDescription: Leslie Gomez, a board-certified nurse family nurse practitioner (FNP-C), demonstrates a step-by-step process for conducting a saline nasal rinse. Instructions: 1. Pour ingredients and water into the sinus rinse bottle up to the dotted line. If you were instructed to add medication, add it in along with the saline packet. **You can also warm it up in the microwave for about 30 seconds until lukewarm if you prefer for comfort. 2. Secure the tip of the nozzle into one nostril and bend forward over the sink or shower. With the nozzle pointed towards the top of your head, gently squeeze the bottle. The water will flush out your nose and sinus cavities and exit through your opposite nostril or your mouth. Try not to swallow the water, spit it out instead. Rinse about half of the bottle through each side. Make sure you lean forward from the waist and tuck your chin close to your chest. 3. Clean the bottle 1-2 times per week. Rinse out the bottle and wash the tip daily with soap and water. Allow to air dry. About once a week, clean the bottle and the tip by mixing equal parts water and hydrogen peroxide or equal parts water and bleach, shake it thoroughly and squirt the solution out of the tip to clean it through. You can also wash the bottle and tip in the dishwasher 1-2 times per week. Saline Rinse Recipe: 1 teaspoon NON-iodized salt 1 teaspoon baking soda Dissolve in 1 quart (32oz) of boiled or distilled water. Learn More about Leslie Gomez, MSN, FNP-C: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33228/ent-head-and-neck-(otolaryngology) Get information about Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/otolaryngology/pages/default.aspx 0:00 - Introduction 0:15 - Preferred rinse bottle 0:26 - How to prepare 0:40 - Fill the bottle 1:10 - Body position and process 2:17 - Rinse demonstration 2:30 - After rinse advice 2:52 - Rinse bottle care
tags: Nasal rinse,Saline,Sinus rinse,Saline nasal rinse,sinus treatment,sinus flush,how to clean sinuses,Nose rinse
caption: true

videoTitle: Patient Full of Gratitude After Facing Cancer Three Times
videoDescription: Phyllis Schwartz, a former news executive, knows firsthand what a cancer diagnosis is like. She has been through treatment for three different types of cancers – Hodgkins’s lymphoma, breast cancer and pancreatic cancer. Her most recent diagnosis was pancreatic neuroendocrine cancer. She did her research and decided to receive her cancer care with Andrew Lowy, MD, FACS, surgical oncologist and chief of the Division of Surgical Oncology at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health. Schwartz underwent the Whipple procedure, a complex surgery that takes several hours and involves removal of the pancreas head and then the duodenum, the first portion of the small bowel. Now, nearly five years post the surgery, Schwartz is living a full life and full of gratitude to the entire medical team who treated her. She is a book author and is using her journey to help others through her writing. To learn more about cancer services at UC San Diego Health, visit https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/Pages/default.aspx
tags: Cancer,UC San Diego Health,Pancreatic Cancer,Breast Cancer,Hodgkins’s lymphoma,Moores Cancer Center,Whipple procedure,Author,Cancer survivor

videoTitle: Outpatient Infusion Program for Sickle Cell Crises Addresses Health Care Inequity
videoDescription: During the pandemic, UC San Diego Health launched a same-day infusion program for patients with sickle cell disease in extreme pain. The outpatient program is an alternative to the emergency department. Sickle cell disease is a devastating inherited blood disorder that disproportionally affects individuals of African and Hispanic descent. Patients with the condition periodically experience excruciating pain when unhealthy red blood cells block blood flow through tiny blood vessels to the chest, abdomen and joints. Over time, the lack of oxygen to organs and tissues causes permanent damage. “We developed a novel approach to caring for patients with sickle cell disease in medical crisis,” said Srila Gopal, MBBS, hematologist and medical director of the adult sickle cell program at UC San Diego Health. “For patients in sickle cell crisis, intense pain can be accompanied by anemia and infections leading to tissue damage and strokes. Unfortunately, these patients often face bias and discrimination from providers who incorrectly assume that requests for pain management are a 'drug seeking' behavior for opioids rather than a legitimate health emergency.” “Sickle cell disease is a disease of significant health care disparities,” said Patty Maysent, CEO, UC San Diego Health. “Our team took the initiative to investigate the issue and to develop an effective telemedicine strategy and program to help patients receive patient-centered care in a timely fashion.” https://health.ucsd.edu/news/releases/Pages/2022-12-12-uc-san-diego-health-recognized-for-health-equity-in-care-of-sickle-cell-crisis.aspx To learn more about the sickle cell program, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/news/pages/default.aspx
tags: UC San Diego Health,UCSD,Sickle Cell,Infusion Center,San Diego Hospital,Health Care Inequity,California Public Hospital,Patty Maysent,blood disorder,anemia,vaso-occulsive crisis
caption: true

videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Awarded Advanced Certification in Spine Surgery
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health has earned The Joint Commission’s Gold Seal of Approval for Advanced Certification in Spine Surgery (ACSS) by meeting or exceeding the highest level of national performance standards. The Gold Seal represents a symbol of quality that reflects a health care organization’s demonstrated ability to implement result-driven processes and advance patient outcomes. UC San Diego Health is the first health organization in California to receive the advanced certification. The certification was achieved through an interdisciplinary collaboration between the Department of Neurological Surgery and the Department of Orthopedic Surgery at UC San Diego Health. Offered in collaboration with the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, the certification is granted to organizations with data-driven care processes, patient safeguards and demonstrated high quality patient outcomes with low complication profiles. UC San Diego Health is the regional referral center for complex spine reconstructions and a national leader in minimally invasive spine surgery, as well as other surgical and non-surgical treatments for spinal disorders. To read more about this distinction, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/news/releases/Pages/2022-11-07-uc-san-diego-health-awarded-advanced-certification-in-spine-surgery.aspx
tags: UC San Diego Health,UCSD,Spine Surgery,Top Spine Surgeons,Neurosurgery,Orthopedic surgery,The Joint Commission,San Diego,advanced certification spine surgery
caption: true

videoTitle: Patient with Prosthetic Legs Inspires Medical Team
videoDescription: Tanner Hopson's world was forever changed when a backache turned into a life-threatening case of sepsis in 2019. After being transferred to UC San Diego Health, it was determined both of his legs would need to be amputated to save his life from the serious blood infection. A multi-disciplinary team at UC San Diego Health treated Tanner to help him return to optimal function after the life-altering event. “I'm thankful to be alive. There really is no other reason other than a miracle and what UC San Diego Health did to keep my body going,” Hopson said. “I am thankful for my mindset because I have the ability to use the functions I do have and do amazing things with them.” Hopson learned how to overcome the challenges he faced and is now inspiring many as he continues to meet significant milestones in his recovery, even training for sporting events, like the Paralympic Games. “It’s so great to see him in clinic walking and continuing to push forward and optimize his function to the point that he’s competing in outdoor events," said Joel Castellanos, MD. “It’s one of those things where it fills up your tank as a provider, it just makes it all worth it." This holiday season we are especially grateful for patients like Tanner, who inspire us and our medical teams who provide exceptional care to our patients. To learn more about UC San Diego Health visit health.ucsd.edu
caption: true

videoTitle: Couple Who Married In Hospital During Pandemic Returns To Say Thank You
videoDescription: In 2020, David Reynoso spent weeks at Jacobs Medical Center in need of a heart and kidney transplant. Much of that time, unfortunately, was away from family and loved ones as visitors were not allowed in the hospital in order to protect patients during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. While waiting for his new heart, however, nurses coordinated a special ceremony for David: a wedding to his love of 11 years, Vicky Young. (https://go.ucsd.edu/3xuGoKO) On July 15, 2020 David received his heart transplant and soon after, his kidney. Two years later, the Reynoso’s have returned to visit their team of nurses, physicians and staff, and say “thank you” to the team that cared for David and helped organize their special day. Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center is the region's first academic-based facility to combine all heart and vascular-related services, programs and technology under one roof. The technologies, techniques and treatments we develop at UC San Diego Health are setting new standards in vascular and cardiac care — for our patients and for the world. Learn more about the services the center is a global leader in, visit: https://healthlocations.ucsd.edu/la-jolla/9434-medical-center-drive Our center is a national hub of clinical expertise and research, and the region's leader in transplantation. Since 1968, our team has performed thousands of transplants under a national standard model of care. See the comprehensive services our team delivers, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/transplant/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Head & Neck Cancer Care With Dr. Joseph A. Califano III, Otolaryngologist
videoDescription: Otolaryngologist Joseph Califano, MD, explains why UC San Diego Health is the only health care system in the region that delivers truly personalized cancer care. He discusses our nationally ranked head and neck cancer program, which allows patients to receive tailored treatment plans and access to innovative surgeries, radiation techniques, and medication. The head and neck care team treats cancers, benign tumors, and other disorders of the head and neck with compassion and state-of-the-art treatments. They specialize in minimally invasive surgery, robotic surgeries, reconstruction and rehabilitation, proton therapy and other radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. With support from the Gleiberman Head and Neck Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health, they offer access to exciting research and clinical trials that are available only at UC San Diego Health. More about our head and neck cancer care: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/head-neck/Pages/default.aspx This video is part of our monthly "Focus on Health" series featuring UC San Diego experts discussing health topics relevant to our community. See more videos in this series: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLp5o_4MxOoYQp05t-pJc8AVrmJGB8MXQH Dr. Califano is a board-certified otolaryngologist who specializes in head and neck surgical oncology. At UC San Diego Health, Dr. Califano is director of the Gleiberman Head and Neck Cancer Center. More about Dr. Califano: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32523/ent-head-and-neck-(otolaryngology)-cancer

videoTitle: What It's Like to Receive Dialysis Treatment
videoDescription: "It's time for you to have dialysis." After Gustavo Guzman was treated for testicular cancer, his diminished kidney function required dialysis. Guzman was hesitant to start his new treatment plan but quickly learned to cope and adjust. Before dialysis, he was unable to walk or be active. He thanks UC San Diego Health for saving his life and helping him live a normal life with some planning and modifications. Learn more about dialysis services at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/kidney/pages/dialysis.aspx 0:20 What led you to be on dialysis? 0:44 How often do you need treatment? 1:00 Tell us about the first time you had dialysis treatment? 2:01 Walk us through a dialysis treatment. 3:17 Do you have to get treatments for the rest of your life? 3:28 Are you a candidate for a kidney transplant? 3:54 Have you experienced side effects from dialysis? 4:29 Is there a special diet you have to follow to ensure dialysis is effective? 5:10 After receiving treatment are you able to work? 5:54 What do you do when you go on vacation? 6:36 Is there anything you would like to say to your kidneys? 7:20 How has UC San Diego Health helped you? #WhatItsLike​​ #Dialysis
tags: Dialysis,Kidney failure,Testicular cancer,kidney,What It's Like,Dialysis treatment
caption: true

videoTitle: Meet Jeffrey Steinberg, MD: Neurosurgeon
videoDescription: More about Dr. Steinburg: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1982044715/neurosurgery Jeffrey Steinberg, MD, is a neurosurgeon who specializes in vascular diseases of the nervous system. He treats aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations (AVM), dural arteriovenous fistulas (dural AVF), stroke, moyamoya disease, intracranial hemorrhage, carotid disease, cavernous malformations, and trigeminal neuralgia. He also treats brain tumors, such as meningiomas. Dr. Steinburg completed specialized training in both open and endovascular neurosurgery, as well as cerebral bypass procedures. He believes in treating every patient as he would his own family member. More about Neurological Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/neuro/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Dog Meets Baby 'Sister' After Her 2-Month Stay in NICU | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Ella Cho was born premature and spent more than 50 days in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) at Jacobs Medical Center at UC San Diego Health in La Jolla. Ella received specialized care by the amazing medical staff. During her stay, her parents, Yumi and Stas Cho, would bring their dog, Proton, to visit outside of Jacobs Medical Center in anticipation of meeting his new "sister." Proton, who brings positivity to everyone he meets, now has his own Instagram page where he documented his life experiences. https://www.instagram.com/p/CY5gj7nuLmk/ In late January 2022, Ella was allowed to go home with her parents. The first thing on her list was meeting Proton. The family documented the precious moment. The NICU at Jacobs Medical Center is a Level III, nationally recognized center of excellence, providing the highest level of care available for premature or sick newborns. UC San Diego Health is the only medical center in San Diego to have both a regional NICU and a labor and delivery service in the same facility. To learn more about pregnancy and childbirth services, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/pregnancy-birth/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: TMS Therapy Used to Treat Severe Depression | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Teresa Lindhardt, 55, had major depressive disorder, also called clinical depression. It affects how a person feels, thinks and behaves and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems. It is the leading cause of disability in the U.S. for people ages 15 to 44, affecting more than 16 million American adults, according to the National Institute of Mental Health. After six weeks of daily treatments with transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) at UC San Diego Health, Lindhardt said she was free of the symptoms of depression that disrupted, and twice nearly ended, her life. “For me, this has been the most life-changing thing that has ever happened,” said Lindhardt. UC San Diego Health was the first provider in San Diego to offer transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) for individuals with hard-to-treat depression and now has the largest and most advanced TMS clinic in the region. Our physicians continue to be at the forefront of innovation for targeted, personalized mental health care. More about TMS for depression: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/behavioral-mental-health/depression-treatment/Pages/tms.aspx Zafiris "Jeff" Daskalakis, MD, PhD, FRCP, is the chair of psychiatry at UC San Diego Health and internationally recognized expert in treating severe psychiatric disorders with magnetic brain stimulation, also known as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). He uses TMS to help patients with treatment-resistant depression and is the director of UC San Diego Health's Interventional Psychiatry Clinic, the region's largest clinic dedicated to treating severe depression with brain stimulation approaches. More about Dr. Daskalakis: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1114516945/psychiatry
tags: clinical depression,major depression,major depression disorder,TMS,transcranial magnetic stimulation,UC San Diego Health,hard to treat depression,how to treat depression,mental health therapy,Zafiris "Jeff" Daskalakis,Dr. Jeff Daskalakis,dysfunctional brain patterns,psychiatrist,psychiatry,TMS clinic in california,tms clinic in San Diego,MagVenture TMS Therapy,BrainsWay's Deep TMS,TMS Theta Burst Stimulation (TBS),hope for those who suffer from depression,ucsd

videoTitle: Patient Makes Video to Thank Health Care Workers | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Anyone who pays attention to the news right now understands how tough things are for health care staff worldwide. A patient sent a note and this video to Patty Maysent, CEO of UC San Diego Health, to say how fantastic everyone was during a recent surgery and to express gratitude for those who made it possible. "At this point in the pandemic, I’m sure every shift is a juggle to staff and schedule from cleaning the rooms to all the departmental sign-offs needed for discharging a patient," Maysent said. "Each person is still on the top of their game ─ just a big 'wow' to everyone at UC San Diego Health." We join with the entire San Diego community to say a heartfelt thank you for their sacrifices and commitment to excellence. We're proud to share their stories. To share your gratitude, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/health-care-heroes.aspx Video Credit: Lyon & Associates Creative Services (NOTE: The videos of the team members were captured during a time of the pandemic when there was low transmission of the COVID-19 virus.)

videoTitle: GERD: Doctor Explains Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Gastroesophageal reflux disease, also known as GERD, is a digestive disorder. It's caused when gastric acid from your stomach flows back up into your food pipe (esophagus). Heartburn is the most common symptom of GERD. Rena Yadlapati, MD, is a board-certified gastroenterologist who specializes in esophageal diseases. Dr. Yadlapati is medical director of the Center for Esophageal Diseases at UC San Diego Health and treats gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and related conditions such as voice complaints (laryngopharyngeal reflux), swallowing disorders such as achalasia and esophageal motility disorders, eosinophilic esophagitis, and Barrett's esophagus. To learn more about Dr. Yadlapati, visit: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33196/gastroenterology At UC San Diego Health, our nationally recognized gastroenterologists provide comprehensive, innovative and compassionate care. And, because our physicians are on the frontline of gastroenterology research, patients have access to some of the latest technological advances, treatments and therapies available. Learn more at: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/gastro/areas-expertise/Pages/gastroenterology.aspx 0:10 How common is GERD 1:39 What tests are available to diagnose GERD? 2:40 How important is it to make lifestyle changes to manage GERD? 3:50 What is laryngopharyngeal reflux? 4:45 Will my symptoms from GERD ever get better?

videoTitle: Meet Sharona Ben-Haim, MD: Neurosurgeon and Director, Surgical Epilepsy Program
videoDescription: More about Dr. Ben-Haim: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32620/neurosurgery-surgery Sharona Ben-Haim, MD, is a neurosurgeon who specializes in caring for people with treatment-resistant epilepsy and movement disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, dystonia and essential tremor and spasticity. She also treats chronic pain, including facial pain and trigeminal neuralgia, as well as pain related to spinal conditions. Her approach to care is highly patient-centered. Dr. Ben-Haim performs deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgeries, including "awake" microelectrode-guided DBS and "asleep" MRI- and CT-guided DBS. She is an expert in leading-edge surgical epilepsy treatments, including selective temporal lobectomies, responsive neurostimulation, and MRI-guided laser induced interstitial thermotherapy (laser ablation) for treatment-resistant epilepsy, as well as gamma knife radiosurgery. More about Neurological Care: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/neuro/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Meet Jeffrey Scott Pannell, MD: Endovascular Neurosurgeon and Neurointerventional Radiologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Pannell: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32496/neurosurgery-radiology Jeffrey Scott Pannell, MD, is a board-certified endovascular surgeon and interventional neuroradiologist, and director of neurointerventional surgery in the Department of Neurological Surgery at UC San Diego Health. Dr. Pannell specializes in the minimally invasive catheter-based treatment of blood vessel disorders that can lead to hemorrhagic or ischemic strokes. This includes cerebral aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), carotid stenosis, intracranial atherosclerotic disease, and other cerebral as well as spinal vascular malformations. He also specializes in the treatment of pain disorders of the spine and cerebrospinal fluid leaks as well as diagnostic neuroradiology. More about neurosurgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/neuro/Pages/neurosurgery.aspx Stroke Care: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/stroke/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Heart Brothers: Two Heart Transplant Recipients Forge Unique Friendship | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Isaac Gonzalez, 19, and George Jimenez, 56, met at the Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center after their respective heart transplant surgeries. They quickly became a source of inspiration and support for each other. The UC San Diego Health heart transplant program is ranked #2 in the nation for one-year patient survival rates among programs with 100 to 120 heart transplants performed. More about our transplant survival rates: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/transplant-programs/ Led by Drs. Victor Pretorius and Eric Adler, our heart transplant program has grown to be the largest in San Diego and the third largest in California, placing it among the nation's top-performing transplant centers. In addition, our results exceed national standards for heart transplantation for people with irreversible, life-threatening heart disease. Learn more at: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/transplant-programs/heart In September 2020, UC San Diego Health became the first hospital on the West Coast to perform heart transplant surgery from a donor after circulatory death, or DCD, using a new portable organ care system. The successful surgery is part of a national interventional clinical trial that could increase organ donation by an estimated 20-30 percent, resulting in less waiting time for patients in need of a new heart. Read more: https://health.ucsd.edu/news/releases/Pages/2020-09-15-uc-san-diego-health-revives-non-beating-donor-heart-for-successful-tansplantation.aspx
tags: UC San Diego Health,UCSD Health,UC San Diego,Heart Transplants,Heart tranplant,cardiac transplant,teenager heart recipient,man receives heart,heart brothers,san diego,hospital procedure,grateful patients,Bio: Dr. Victor Pretorius,Dr. Pretorius,heart failure,congestive heart failure,heart attack,DCD,donor heart,donor list,what's it like to get a new heart,sulpizio cardiovascular center,la jolla,best heart transplant hospital

videoTitle: Total Knee Replacement Surgery | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Each person's knee is different. This is why UC San Diego Health offers several surgical options for knee replacements to tailor care to each person's injury and health. Each surgical approach has benefits for the right surgical candidate. Our surgeons can discuss what option is most appropriate for each person. To learn more about knee replacement options at UC San Diego Health, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/orthopedics/joint-replacement/Pages/knee.aspx Francis Gonzales, MD, is a board-certified orthopedic surgeon who specializes in adult hip and knee joint replacement surgery. Learn more about Dr. Gonzales: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11935/orthopedics UC San Diego Health is repeatedly ranked among the nation's best in orthopedic care by U.S. News & World Report. We are also a Blue Distinction Center recognized for our treatment expertise and better overall patient results for knee replacement, as well as a designated Center of Excellence for orthopedic care by Optum. This means you'll receive expert, safe and cost-effective care. UC San Diego Health's orthopedic surgeons are the first and only in San Diego to offer customized knee replacements with the ROSA knee system — for a faster recovery and more natural feeling knee. Talk to one of our surgeons about whether a ROSA knee replacement is right for you. https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/orthopedics/joint-replacement/Pages/knee.aspx#a

videoTitle: Meet Jennifer T. Anger, MD, MPH: Urologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Anger: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1114949807/urology-surgery Jennifer T. Anger, MD, MPH, (she/her) is a board-certified female pelvic medicine expert and reconstructive urology surgeon who is experienced in treating pelvic floor disorders in men and women. She is the only physician in San Diego who performs gender-affirming pelvic, or "bottom," surgery. Dr. Anger also serves patients who need repeat surgery (revision surgery). And she helps people who've had complications from other surgeries. She leads the gender-affirming pelvic surgery program at UC San Diego Health and is part of the transgender care team. She also has expertise in robotic-assisted pelvic floor reconstruction. Dr. Anger is committed to shared decision-making and a patient-centered approach to care. And she is dedicated to improving the quality of care and access for underserved populations, including aging women with pelvic floor disorders. Urogynecology and Pelvic Reconstructive Surgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/gynecology/urogynecology/Pages/default.aspx Urology Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/urology/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Meet Cynthia Gyamfi-Bannerman, MD: Perinatologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Gyamfi-Bannerman: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/1568494250/obstetrics-gynecology Dr. Cynthia Gyamfi-Bannerman is a board-certified perinatologist who specializes in caring for women with high-risk pregnancies. She is internationally recognized for her work and focuses on preterm birth, both in prevention and in the use of antenatal corticosteroids, or steroids. She likes to get to know her patients personally so they are comfortable communicating about their needs and wishes throughout their pregnancy. Dr. Gyamfi-Bannerman also serves as chair and professor in the Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Reproductive Sciences at UC San Diego Health. More about Perinatal Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/pregnancy-birth/prenatal/maternal-fetal-medicine/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Meet Joseph Osorio, MD, PhD: Neurosurgeon and Director, Spinal Oncology and Deformity Surgery
videoDescription: More about Dr. Osorio: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33208/neurosurgery-surgery Joseph Osorio, MD, PhD, is a neurosurgeon who directs the spinal oncology and deformity surgery program at UC San Diego Health. He specializes in complex spine surgery and treats spinal conditions such as scoliosis, kyphosis, kyphoscoliosis and flatback syndrome. He also treats spinal tumors, cervical spinal problems, and degenerative conditions of the spine such as spondylolisthesis and stenosis. Dr. Osorio completed training in both neurosurgical and orthopedic spine surgery. This means he can look at spine conditions from many perspectives and recommend the best treatment tailored for each patient. More about Complex Spine Care: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/neuro/specialty-programs/spine-center/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: What It’s Like to Experience a Pregnancy Loss | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: When it comes to loss, one of the most difficult things a person can experience is the death of a child. Kayla Lauriano, a Labor and Delivery nurse with a passion for bereavement care, experienced an ectopic pregnancy resulting in emergency surgery in 2020. Her experience coupled with her passion for supporting those who inspired her to create Wounded Womb, a workshop dedicated to moving through the emotions of grief with breath work, asana and story sharing. She is a Resolve Through Sharing coordinator, a prenatal/perinatal loss yoga instructor and a photographer whose work focuses on motherhood and labor and delivery. She volunteers her time and expertise to capture the first and last moments for families experiencing the devastating loss of their baby. Learn more about maternal mental health care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/behavioral-mental-health/reproductive/ 0:17 What motivated you to share your experience and work with other women who have experienced pregnancy loss? 1:17 How did you discover your pregnancy was ectopic? 2:06 What is an ectopic pregnancy? 2:39 What were your treatment options? 3:57 Did you feel any guilt surrounding the loss of your child? 5:57 How do you feel about the term miscarriage versus pregnancy loss? 6:49 What has your healing journey looked like? 7:38 Did you receive any well-meaning but negative support from your network? #WhatItsLike​​ #PregnancyLoss #EctopicPregnancy #WoundedWomb
