videoTitle: Refuerzo y Vacunas COVID-19: Un Doctor Responde sus Preguntas
videoDescription: Edward Cachay, MD, médico de enfermedades infecciosas de UC San Diego Health, responde a preguntas sobre las vacunas contra el COVID-19. 0:20 ¿Por qué debe usted recibir la vacuna contra el COVID-19? 0:52 ¿Cómo actúan las vacunas contra el COVID-19? 1:36 ¿Podría contraer el COVID-19 si es que recibo cualquier vacuna? 1:54 ¿Cuán efectivas son las vacunas disponibles para protegerlo de las nuevas variantes que están emergiendo producto del COVID-19? 2:34 ¿Puedo infectarme a pesar de haber recibido la vacuna contra el COVID-19? 3:06 ¿Cómo se llama desde el punto de vista técnico cuando una persona se infecta, a pesar de haber sido vacunado? 3:41 ¿Cuánto tiempo va a durar mi protección luego de recibir una vacuna? 4:40 ¿Cuál es la diferencia entre una dosis extra y la dosis de refuerzo o “booster”? 5:52 ¿Quiénes son las personas que pueden beneficiarse de la dosis extra para la vacuna contra el COVID-19? 7:01 ¿Dónde puedo recibir la dosis extra para el COVID-19? 7:26 ¿Puedo necesitar una vacuna de refuerzo o un booster cada año? 8:00 ¿Cuánto debo esperar para recibir mi dosis de refuerzo o booster para la vacuna contra el COVID-19? 8:15 ¿Puedo recibir el mismo tipo de vacuna de refuerzo cuando lo necesite? 8:46 ¿Cuáles son los beneficios reales de recibir una dosis adicional? 9:03 ¿Los efectos adversos luego de recibir la dosis de refuerzo o booster de la vacuna son los mismos? 9:27 ¿Debo recibir la vacuna luego de haberme infectado? 9:37 ¿Puedo obtener la vacuna para el flu (influenza) y la COVID-19 de refuerzo al mismo tiempo? 10:07 ¿Puedo tomar Tylenol o alguna otra medicina como ibuprofeno para los efectos colaterales? 10:49 ¿Cuáles son los efectos de las vacunas de COVID-19 en las mujeres que quieren quedar embarazadas o en las mujeres que están embarazadas? 11:13 ¿Pueden y deben recibir la vacuna contra el COVID-19 las personas embarazadas? (Más información: los CDC y profesionales médicos recomiendan la vacunación COVID-19 para las personas que quieren tener hijos https://espanol.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/planning-for-pregnancy.html) Más sobre las vacunas contra el COVID-19 en UC San Diego Health: https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=&sl=en&tl=es&u=https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/vaccine.aspx Más sobre el Dr. Cachay: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11724/hiv-aids-infectious-diseases

videoTitle: Why You Should Get the HPV Vaccine
videoDescription: Dominique Rash, MD, radiation oncology, shares why the HPV vaccine is a safe and effective way to prevent diseases ranging from genital warts to certain kinds of cancer. If you're interested in scheduling an appointment to receive the HPV vaccine, she recommends talking to your doctor to see if the vaccine is right for you. She also suggests parents get their adolescent children vaccinated to protect them against different kinds of HPV. Make an appointment with your primary care provider to get the HPV vaccine: https://health.ucsd.edu/request_appt/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Meet Matthew Meunier, MD: Orthopedic Surgeon
videoDescription: More about Dr. Meunier: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11596/orthopedics-sports-medicine Matthew Meunier, MD, is a board-certified orthopedic surgeon who specializes in hand, upper extremity and microvascular surgery to treat a variety of conditions, including fractures and dislocations, shoulder injuries, chronic wrist pain, and congenital hand disorders. He is one of the region's top hand injury experts. He was a consultant physician for the San Diego Chargers. In college, Dr. Meunier played competitive rugby and squash. He enjoys staying active through running, cycling and surfing. Orthopedic Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/orthopedics/Pages/default.aspx
caption: true

videoTitle: Meet Rena Yadlapati, MD: Gastroenterologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Yadlapati: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33196/gastroenterology Dr. Rena Yadlapati is medical director of the Center for Esophageal Diseases at UC San Diego Health. She treats gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and related conditions such as voice complaints (laryngopharyngeal reflux), swallowing disorders such as achalasia, and esophageal motility disorders, eosinophilic esophagitis, and Barrett's esophagus. She provides personalized care using the latest integrated and holistic approaches to these conditions. Our physicians are international leaders who developed many of the current guidelines for treating and managing esophageal diseases. More at esophageal care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/gastro/areas-expertise/esophageal/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center: Celebrating 10 Years of World-Class Care
videoDescription: Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center at UC San Diego Health has marked many firsts in the ten years since its completion in 2011. This includes the first hybrid operating room with a built-in cath lab in the region to the first robotically assisted coronary stent procedure on West Coast. Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center now houses the largest robot-assisted angioplasty program in world and we train people from across the globe, according to Dr. Ehtisham Mahmud, executive director of medicine at UC San Diego Health's Cardiovascular Institute. When Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center opened, “Our hope was that no patient in San Diego County would ever have to leave the San Diego area for any cardiovascular care, says Dr. Michael Madani, executive director of surgery at the Cardiovascular Institute. “And we accomplished that within the first couple of years.” More information about cardiovascular care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/heart More about Dr. Mahmud: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11404/cardiology More about Dr. Madani: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11956/cardiothoracic-(heart-and-lung)-surgery-cardiology 0:00 - Intro 0:30 - How it Started 1:20 - 2011 Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center Opens 1:58 - Early Success 2:45 - Prominent CTEPH & BPA Programs 3:45 - Adult Congenital Heart Disease 4:00 - Cardiovascular Institute Established 4:20 - Our Research Mission 4:45 - 4000th PTE Surgery Performed 5:20 - Pandemic Response 5:45 - Quality & Outcome Rankings 6:35 - Looking Forward
tags: Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center,UC San Diego Health cardiovascular care,Heart surgery San Diego,CTEPH,PTE,BPA,robotic assisted angioplasty,Cath lab,Hybrid operating room,Cardiologists San Diego,Dr. Ehtisham Mahmud,Dr. Michael Madani
caption: true

videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Administers 500,000 Vaccines
videoDescription: In January 2021, UC San Diego Health answered the call to launch the first COVID-19 vaccination superstation in the region. Since this effort began, more than 236,000 San Diegans have received doses from UC San Diego Health vaccination sites. “To have administered 500,000 vaccines to community members is an incredible accomplishment and one that we couldn’t have achieved without our dedicated health care teams and volunteers,” said Patty Maysent, CEO of UC San Diego Health. “I am extremely grateful for their efforts and proud of UC San Diego Health’s role in helping our region through this pandemic.” Thank you to the #HealthCareHeroes, volunteers, community partners and community members who made this possible. More about COVID-19 vaccination information at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/vaccine.aspx

videoTitle: What It Means to Be San Diego's Only Comprehensive Cancer Center
videoDescription: Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health is San Diego's only National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center. This is the highest possible rating for a cancer center in the United States, reserved for places pushing the boundaries to prevent and treat all types of cancer. In this video, Lisa Parry, MD, a board-certified colon and rectal surgeon at UC San Diego Health explains what makes our cancer care special and the advantages of having truly personalized cancer care. UC San Diego Health's doctors and nurses treat every type of cancer, most importantly yours. videoTitle: San Diego Connect: Anne Wallace, MD, on Breast Cancer Care
videoDescription: One in eight women born in the U.S. will develop breast cancer sometime in her life. In this video, Anne Wallace, MD, a board-certified breast cancer surgeon at UC San Diego Health, discusses signs and symptoms of breast cancer. Dr. Wallace, who also directs UC San Diego Health's Comprehensive Breast Health Center, explains why it is important for all women to think about their long-term health and ability to access to comprehensive care in the event of a serious or complex disease such as breast cancer. She explains how UC San Diego Health personalizes each person’s care to give each woman the best possible outcome. This includes offering treatment through clinical trials participation. videoTitle: After Brain Cancer Surgery Sabrina Leamon Returns to Daily Life
videoDescription: When, at 24-years-old, Sabrina Leamon began to experience fogginess and anxiety she knew something was wrong. After experiencing two seizures, Sabrina finally knew the root of her symptoms. In 2020, in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, Sabrina was diagnosed with a slow-growing brain cancer called a grade II diffuse glioma. She recommends that if you think something is wrong, don’t delay and see your doctor today. After the diagnosis, Sabrina looked for a healthcare team with expertise in treating her type of cancer. She found personalized cancer care under Thomas L. Beaumont, MD, PhD, neurosurgeon at UC San Diego Health who specializes in skull base and minimally invasive cranial surgery and brain tumors. UC San Diego Health — home to the region’s only comprehensive brain tumor program and only National Cancer Institute-designated comprehensive cancer center — has an internationally recognized team of experts in neuro-oncology, neurosurgery, radiation oncology, neuroradiology, neuropathology and neuroimaging for the comprehensive research and treatment of benign and malignant brain tumors. More information about brain tumor treatments at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/brain/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Celebrates Vaccine Super Station Milestones
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health team members reflect on the milestones and accomplishments of the Petco Park Vaccination Super Station. In total, the site, which was a collaboration between UC San Diego Health, the County of San Diego, the City of San Diego and the San Diego Padres, administered more than 225,000 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine to the community. It all started with one phone call in early January. Five days later, the 280,000-square-foot site was opened. The remarkable effort required strong partnerships, inspired leadership and a comprehensive team effort. More about COVID-19 vaccines at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/vaccine.aspx

videoTitle: Novel Treatment for Severe Depression
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health's Interventional Psychiatry Clinic offers an innovative form of brain stimulation, known as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) to treat severe depression in people who have not responded to antidepressant medications or talk therapy. In this video, the clinic's director, Dr. Jeff Daskalakis, an internationally recognized expert in brain stimulation, explains how TMS works and why you receive better care for depression at UC San Diego Health. Hard-to-treat depression is common. Novel treatments, such as TMS, provide relief for many people who have not responded to traditional approaches. videoTitle: What It’s Like to Participate in a Clinical Trial | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: The best cancer care is personalized cancer care. Cat Circo, 32, was diagnosed with cervical cancer. Her cancer was growing rapidly and she decided to enroll in a clinical trial offered at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health. The trial was investigating the optimal sequence of immunotherapy and chemoradiation. Cat describes her experience of going through a clinical trial and how the teams at UC San Diego Health provided extra layers of personalized care. As an NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center, Moores Cancer Center has the ability to translate scientific findings straight from the laboratory to the patient with the ability to tailor and personalize treatment. In many cases, innovative treatments and particular clinical trials are only available at UC San Diego Health. To learn more, visit https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/about/Pages/default.aspx?utm_source=Social&utm_medium=YouTube&utm_campaign=CancerCampaign21 Read Cat’s story here: https://health.ucsd.edu/news/releases/pages/2020-07-23-cancer-clinical-trials-tested-continue-during-covid-pandemic.aspx?utm_source=Social&utm_medium=YouTube&utm_campaign=CancerCampaign21 0:18 What is a clinical trial? 1:22 How did you find out about the clinical trial? 2:23 How long did it take to start the clinical trial? 2:48 What are the pros of participating in a clinical trial? 3:59 What are the cons of participating in a clinical trial? 4:27 Did the clinical trial work? 4:45 Did you get the placebo? 5:40 What choose UC San Diego Health for your cancer care? 6:39 How did people support you during the clinical trial? 8:13 What advice would you give someone considering participating in a clinical trial? #WhatItsLike​​ #ClinicalTrial #MooresCancerCenter #UniqueCancerCare #CervicalCancer

videoTitle: Meet Seth K. Bechis, MD: Urologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Bechis: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32758/urology-surgery Seth Bechis, MD, is a board-certified urologist who cares for patients with diseases of the urinary tract, including kidney stones — both surgical treatment and prevention — benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or enlarged prostate, and men's health issues. He has surgical expertise in percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) for complex stones, ureteroscopy and shockwave lithotripsy. Dr. Bechis likes to education patients on their conditions so that they can make more informed choices about their treatments. Being able to relieve pain and restore a patient’s health are the most rewarding aspects of his job. Dr. Bechis specializes in all procedures of the prostate including minimally invasive procedures such as Rezum water vapor therapy and UroLift, as well as robotic surgery and GreenLight™ Laser photoselective vaporization of the prostate (PVP). He is among only a select number of physicians in the country — and the first doctor in California — to be designated as a Center of Excellence for GreenLight™ Laser Therapy. Urology Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/urology/ Kidney Stone Center: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/urology/kidney-stones/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: UC San Diego's Safer at School Early Alert tests for COVID-19 at schools and childcare centers
videoDescription: In an effort to help schools reduce the risk of COVID-19 outbreaks as they resume in-person instruction, University of California San Diego and the County of San Diego are testing the Safer at School Early Alert system, an evidence-based program to detect SARS-CoV-2 at schools and child care centers. Through daily wastewater and surface monitoring, Safer at School Early Alert tests for the presence of particles of the coronavirus. Combined with a responsive testing strategy, the aim is to quickly identify children or staff members who are infected with COVID-19 before an outbreak occurs. Learn more about the Safer at School Early Alert System (SASEA), a COVID-19 wastewater detection pilot program for K-12 schools and daycares: https://hwsph.ucsd.edu/research/programs-groups/sasea.html

videoTitle: What is Reactogenicity?
videoDescription: Reactogenicity refers to reactions that occur soon after vaccination, according to Dr. Marlene Millen, primary care physician and chief medical information officer at UC San Diego Health. She says this reaction is not a side effect of the vaccine. It just means your immune system is working. Some people get more immune response than others, and that's when they might feel a little achy or feverish. More about COVID-19 vaccines at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/vaccine.aspx More about Dr. Millen: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/12013/primary-care-internal-medicine

videoDescription: More about Dr. Derweesh: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11887/urology-cancer Ithaar Derweesh, MD, is a board-certified urologist who subspecializes in urologic tumors and malignancies. Dr. Derweesh has established one of the highest volume kidney cancer surgical programs in North America. He offers an innovative approach to personalized treatment of kidney cancer for localized, locally advanced, and advanced disease. He is one of the world's leading experts for partial nephrectomy for large renal masses, use of minimally invasive surgery and the use of targeted medication to enable kidney-preserving treatments. He also specializes in ablation of kidney masses and renal cell carcinoma. videoTitle: 2020 Reflection from Patty Maysent, CEO | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: We are grateful for the dedication, compassion and bravery of all our UC San Diego Health team members in 2020. Every day during the pandemic, they served patients at the bedside and beyond. From filling pharmacy orders to cleaning and sanitizing rooms, from providing meals to comforting families, from maintaining equipment to pursuing lifesaving research, our team members excel both on the front lines and behind the scenes. Patty Maysent, CEO, shared a heartfelt thank you to the UC San Diego Health teams for their sacrifices and commitment to excellence in 2020. We're proud to share more of our #HealthCareHeroes stories — and offer ways to share your gratitude: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/health-care-heroes.aspx #UCSDHealth #UCSDCares

videoTitle: Hope Rises as UC San Diego Health Staff Receive COVID-19 Vaccine
videoDescription: The first health care workers at UC San Diego Health began receiving their first doses of the COVID-19 vaccine on December 16, 2020. This is a momentous occasion. We are extremely grateful to our patient care and support staff teams, who have been working tirelessly to continue to provide outstanding care to all patients and to keep our patients and each other safe, all while learning how to best care for patients with COVID-19 and building a robust COVID-19 testing system for our community. Until a significant portion of the public is vaccinated, UC San Diego Health urges community members to continue to follow all the public health measures, such as masking, hand washing, staying home, maintaining distance from people outside your immediate household and activating the CA NOTIFY exposure notification app on your smartphone. Learn more at https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/default.aspx To see answers to FAQs about the COVID-19 vaccine, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/vaccine.aspx

videoTitle: Meet Pam R. Taub, MD, FACC: Cardiologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Taub: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11968/cardiology-cardiac-rehabilitation Pam R. Taub, MD, FACC, is a board-certified cardiologist who focuses on general and preventive cardiology, as well as women's cardiovascular health. As a general cardiologist, she works with patients to diagnose and prevent heart disease, as well as manage conditions such as hypertension (high blood pressure), coronary artery disease, or heart failure. She is the founding director of the Step Family Foundation Cardiac Rehabilitation and Wellness Center at Jacobs Medical Center. She focuses on strategies to prevent cardiovascular disease, especially lifestyle changes. Dr. Taub uses an evidence-based approach to care and tailors it to each patient, with the goal of minimizing medications and procedures. She also collaborates closely with other specialists to provide cardiac care for patients with complex, multi-system diseases such as cancer and autoimmune disease. Cardiac Rehabilitation and Wellness: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/cardiac-rehabilitation/ Cardiovascular Services: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/

videoTitle: The COVID Vaccine: Pros, Cons and Which One? | UC San Diego Health COVID Grand Rounds
videoDescription: As the first vaccine shipments arrive at hospitals across the U.S., Dr. Robert “Chip” Schooley, Professor of Medicine in the Division of Infectious Disease, discusses the current state of the pandemic and why we need a vaccine. Topics include the immunobiology of coronavirus infection, the different vaccine platforms, and the vaccine planning efforts at UC San Diego Health. The talk is followed by a Q&A moderated by Dr. Steven Garfin, interim dean of UC San Diego School of Medicine. This event was co-sponsored by UC San Diego School of Medicine and the UCSD Academy of Clinician Scholars. videoTitle: Meet Dr. Roger Sur, MD: Urologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Sur: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11625/urology-surgery Roger Sur, MD, is a board-certified urologist and founder/director of the Comprehensive Kidney Stone Center at UC San Diego Health that focuses on surgical treatment, medical prevention and research into causes of kidney stones. He specializes in percutaneous nephrolithotomy using the latest, minimally invasive techniques. As a professor in the Department of Urology, Dr. Sur instructs medical students, residents and fellows at UC San Diego School of Medicine, where is also program director of the joint UC San Diego-Kaiser Endourology fellowship. He also works as a urologist at VA San Diego Healthcare System and as an associate professor of surgery at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, a military medical school. Dr. Sur's research interests include antimicrobial use in kidney stone surgery, determining genetic causes of kidney stone disease, and minimizing radiation exposure for patients and health providers during endoscopic procedures. His work has appeared in medical and research publications. He has published numerous manuscripts and book chapters, and serves as content reviewer for the American Urological Association. Dr. Sur is also involved in several clinical trials. Urology Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/urology/pages/default.aspx Kidney Stone Center: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/urology/kidney-stones/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Kidney Transplant Patient Turns a Phage
videoDescription: Maria Madrigal was born with a kidney disease that ultimately required removal of both organs, and a new donor kidney. But before and after the transplant, she was plagued by a recurring bacterial infection resistant to antibiotic treatment. So, with assistance from Saima Aslam, MD, and colleagues at UC San Diego Health, Madrigal underwent phage therapy, which involves treating problematic infections with bacteriophages—viruses that specifically target different bacteria. Phage therapy may be part of the answer to the global problem of multidrug-resistant pathogens, and the Center for Innovate Phage Applications and Therapeutics at UC San Diego School of Medicine is leading the way. Read Madrigal’s story: https://health.ucsd.edu/news/features/Pages/2020-12-02-one-for-the-phages.aspx More about Dr. Aslam: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/12044/infectious-diseases IPATH: https://medschool.ucsd.edu/som/medicine/divisions/idgph/research/center-innovative-phage-applications-and-therapeutics/Pages/default.aspx
tags: UC San Diego Health,UC San Diego,UCSD,UCSD Health,San Diego Hospital,Phage,Therapy,bacterial infection resistant to antibiotic treatment,bacterial infection,antibiotic treatement,Therapeutics
caption: false

videoTitle: Paciente de trasplante de riñón recibe una ayuda viral
videoDescription: María Madrigal nació con una enfermedad renal poliquística que finalmente requirió la extracción de ambos órganos y un trasplante de riñón. Pero antes y después del trasplante, estuvo plagada de una infección bacteriana recurrente que es multirresistente a los antibióticos. Con la ayuda de Saima Aslam, MD, y colegas de UC San Diego Health, Madrigal se sometió a una terapia de fagos, que implica el tratamiento de infecciones problemáticas con bacteriófagos, virus que se dirigen específicamente a diferentes bacterias. La terapia con fagos puede ser parte de la respuesta al problema global de los patógenos resistentes a múltiples fármacos, y el Center for Innovate Phage Applications and Therapeutics de UC San Diego School of Medicine está liderando el camino. Lea la historia de Madrigal: https://health.ucsd.edu/news/features/Pages/2020-12-02-paciente-sometida-a-trasplante-de-rinon-y-con-infecciones-recurrentes-recibe-ayuda-viral.aspx Saima Aslam: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/12044/infectious-diseases IPATH: https://medschool.ucsd.edu/som/medicine/divisions/idgph/research/center-innovative-phage-applications-and-therapeutics/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Couple has Open Heart Surgeries Months Apart | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: In early 2020, Steven and Linette Williamson experienced the true meaning of the wedding vow in sickness and in health when they both underwent open heart surgery within just four months of each other. After seven years of treatment for a genetic heart abnormality, Steven was told he needed a heart transplant to save his life. Soon after Steven began his recovery process, Linette was diagnosed with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), and found herself in the care of the same surgeon who performed her husband’s surgery, Dr. Victor Pretorius, Cardiothoracic Surgeon and Surgical Director of the Heart Transplant Program at at UC San Diego Health. Now, both husband and wife are on the road to recovery together. The multidisciplinary Cardiovascular Services team at UC San Diego Health performed more than 70 heart transplants in 2019 and is on pace for exceeding this number in 2020. Annually, this team also performs more than 200 PTE surgeries for CTEPH each year, a procedure that was pioneered at UC San Diego Health. For the 2020-2021 U.S. News & World Report, the cardiology and heart surgery programs at UC San Diego Health ranked 31st among the nation’s top 50 programs, out of 4,500 hospitals nationwide. For more information about the Cardiovascular Institute at UC San Diego Health, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/ To learn more about Victor Pretorius, MBChB, visit: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/12043/cardiothoracic-(heart-and-lung)-surgery-cardiology

videoTitle: Understanding Pelvic Floor Conditions with Dr. Santiago-Lastra | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Women’s Pelvic Medicine Center at UC San Diego Health -https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/gynecology/urogynecology/Pages/default.aspx Dr. Yahir Santiago-Lastra, director of the Women’s Pelvic Medicine Center at UC San Diego Health, discusses some common myths about pelvic floor disorders and offers tips for maintaining bladder health. Nearly half of women will experience some form of pelvic floor dysfunction. But just because an issue is common doesn’t mean that it’s “normal” or untreatable. Many do not seek treatment for pelvic floor disorders out of embarrassment or fear of needing surgery. UC San Diego Health brings together physicians and therapists from urology, gynecology, general surgery and physical therapy to provide the latest diagnostic tools and therapies to women and men who have urinary and bowel incontinence, pelvic organ prolapse, urogenital conditions caused by neurologic disorders, and voiding dysfunction. We offer a range of therapies, from simple, nonsurgical treatment options to more complex reconstructive procedures, in an effort to relieve — or even cure — your condition. More about Dr. Santiago-Lastra - https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32623/urology-surgery More about the PLUS Consortium - https://plusconsortium.umn.edu/

videoTitle: What’s it Like to Live with an LVAD | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Heart patient Hortencia Wagner, who underwent LVAD surgery at UC San Diego Health, carries the device with her wherever she goes and shares her candid experience of living with it. Also known as heart pumps, ventricular assist devices (VADs) are mechanical pumping devices designed to help the heart pump more blood. They work by taking blood from the heart and pumping it to the rest of the body, thus taking the burden off the heart. After undergoing treatment for breast cancer in 2008, Wagner was diagnosed with heart failure just five years later, leading to her heart functioning at just 13%. Through conversations with her care team and loved ones, Hortencia decided to undergo surgery for a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) to save her life. Ventricular assist devices, or VADs, are used to treat heart failure. Learn more: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/heart-failure/vad/ To learn more about cardiovascular treatment programs at UC San Diego Health, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/ To learn more about heart transplants at UC San Diego Health, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/transplant-programs/heart

videoTitle: Meet Catriona Jamieson, MD, PhD: Hematologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Jamieson: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/12046/hematology-blood-diseases-cancer Catriona Jamieson, MD, PhD, is a board-certified hematologist and regenerative medicine specialist with broad clinical expertise in caring for patients with hematologic malignancies. As hematology team leader for the Division of Hematology/Oncology at UC San Diego Health Moores Cancer Center, Dr. Jamieson’s clinical interests include the treatment of myeloproliferative neoplasms including chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), polycythemia vera (PV), myelofibrosis and essential thrombocythemia. She is also the principal investigator on several clinical trials for the treatment of these and related bone marrow disorders. In her own laboratory first at Moores Cancer Center, and now also at the Sanford Consortium for Regenerative Medicine, she has expanded her research to include analysis of the events involved in the initiation and progression of a variety of blood cancers. The continued aims of her research group focus on developing novel therapeutic strategies for hematological malignancies that will improve the quality of life of people with these disorders. videoTitle: Understanding Gynecologic Cancer | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Every five minutes someone is diagnosed with a gynecologic cancer, which includes ovarian, cervical, vulvar, uterine/endometrial and vaginal malignancies. Michael McHale, MD, gynecologic oncologist who specializes in diagnosing and treating cancers related to women's reproductive organs, shares important information about this disease. 0:09 What is a gynecologic cancer? 0:25 What are the signs or symptoms of these diseases? 3:30 What can a woman do to protect herself? 4:35 Should I get HPV vaccine? 5:48 What should I do if I'm diagnosed with a gynecologic cancer? Did you know? • The human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most common sexually transmitted infection and the cause of most cervical cancers and some vaginal cancers. The HPV vaccine has proven effective in preventing infection and six types of HPV-attributable cancers. • The Pap test, which screens for cervical cancer, does not screen for ovarian cancer. • Endometrial cancer is the most common gynecologic cancer. • Vaginal and vulvar cancers usually affects older women. The gynecologic oncologists at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health provide care for women with cancer of the reproductive tract and conduct research to improve diagnosis methods and treatments. https://health.ucsd.edu/care/cancer/cancers-we-treat/gynecologic/ Dr. McHale also serves as surgical director of perioperative services at UC San Diego Health, where he oversees clinical operations. Learn more: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11796/obstetrics-gynecology-cancer #MooresCancerCenter #UCSDHealth #GynecologicCancer

videoTitle: Tests prove masks don’t cause oxygen deficiency & CO2 intoxication
videoDescription: Does wearing a mask hinder breathing—either by reducing oxygen intake or causing carbon dioxide buildup? Some people think so, but these two simple, clinical tests prove otherwise. Masks do not hinder breathing and are an essential part of the effort to reduce coronavirus spread. Pulse oximetry is a simple, noninvasive and painless test often conducted in clinics. A small, clip-like device is attached to a body part, typically a finger, toe or earlobe. It uses infrared light to measure oxygen saturation levels in your blood. The higher the levels of oxygen-carrying hemoglobin in the blood, the more infrared light is absorbed. A normal reading is between 95 and 100 percent. Transcutaneous capnometry is also simple, noninvasive and painless. It measures levels of carbon dioxide infused in body tissues, i.e. CO2 not exhaled. A small sensor is placed on the skin. A normal range is between 30 and 45 millimeters of mercury, which is a unit of measurement of pressure. In the video above, you can see what happens to oxygen and CO2 levels when a person wears a mask(s). Wearing Is Caring: Keeping Each Other Safe During COVID-19 Along with social distancing and frequent hand washing, masks are a simple, yet effective, way to slow the spread of COVID-19. How to Safely Put On and Remove Face Masks: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/masks.aspx To protect patients and health care workers at UC San Diego Health, we require the use of face coverings in all our facilities. It’s one of the steps that we can all take to keep our community healthy. Masks must be worn at all times in public areas and in patient rooms at our hospitals, clinics and labs. Visitors and patients may wear their own cloth mask if it is clean and well-fitting. Your nose, mouth and chin should be covered. Atul Malhotra, MD, is a board-certified pulmonologist, intensivist and research chief of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine. Dr. Malhotra was the recent president of the American Thoracic Society (2015-2016). Learn more about Dr. Malhotra: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/22362/sleep-medicine-pulmonology-(lung) Find out more: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Controlling SARS CoV-2 | UC San Diego Health COVID Grand Rounds
videoDescription: During times of crisis and uncertainty, it can be difficult and overwhelming to sort fact from fiction. In response, physicians at UC San Diego Health have launched the COVID-19 Virtual Grand Rounds Series, a six-part live video symposium that will focus on topics related to the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. Part Four – Controlling SARS-CoV-2 — Lessons from Hong Kong (Aug. 12, 2020): Dr. KY Yuen, Chair of Infectious Diseases at the University of Hong Kong, compares the 2020 Novel Coronavirus to the 2003 SARS outbreak in this 4th video of our Virtual Grand Rounds series. Yuen references the research he led in 2003 that sought to identify and control the source of SARS-CoV to stop recurrence, and improve epidemic preparedness. He also explains the similarities and differences between the viral manifestation of both 2003 SARS-CoV and 2020 SARS-CoV-2, demonstrates the importance of universal masking, and provides insight on future planning as countries around the world continue to address the pandemic. videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Ranked #1 in San Diego - US News and World Report
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health is ranked first in San Diego and sixth in California, placing it among the nation’s best hospitals, according to the 2020-2021 U.S. News & World Report. Read the full report here - https://health.ucsd.edu/news/releases/Pages/2020-07-27-uc-san-diego-ranked-number-one-by-us-news-and-world-report.aspx The annual rankings are designed to assist patients and their doctors in making informed decisions about where to receive care for a variety of health conditions, common elective procedures and complex surgeries. “This is an extraordinary honor that recognizes the dedication of our entire staff and represents the intersection of UC San Diego’s tripartite mission of delivering outstanding patient care through commitment to the community, groundbreaking research and inspired teaching,” said Patty Maysent, CEO, UC San Diego Health. For the 2020-2021 rankings, U.S. News & World Report evaluated more than 4,500 hospitals nationwide in 16 specialties and 10 procedures and conditions. In the 16 specialty areas, just 134 hospitals (2.9 percent) were ranked in at least one specialty. UC San Diego Health was ranked in the top 50 for 10 specialties.

videoTitle: Meet Parag Sanghvi, MD, MSPH: Radiation Oncologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Sanghvi: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11369/radiation-oncology-cancer Parag Sanghvi, MD, MSPH, is a board-certified radiation oncologist who specializes in the treatment and management of skin cancers, head cancers, neck cancers, leukemias, lymphomas and brain tumors. He serves as the department clinical vice chair and the service chief for hematologic malignancies and skin cancers and is the disease team co-leader for hematologic malignancies at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health. In this video, Dr. Sanghvi discusses the benefits of receiving care at Moores Cancer Center, the region's only National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center. The team at Moores Cancer Center works collaboratively and uses the most novel therapies, allowing them to focus on every patient in their individual cancer and develop a treatment plan that is right for them. Learn more about the cancer services at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/about/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Public Health Perspectives on COVID-19 | UC San Diego Health COVID Grand Rounds
videoDescription: During times of crisis and uncertainty, it can be difficult and overwhelming to sort fact from fiction. In response, physicians at UC San Diego Health have launched the COVID-19 Virtual Grand Rounds Series, a six-part live video symposium that will focus on topics related to the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. Part Two – Public Health Perspectives on COVID-19 (July 29, 2020): Two of the nation’s leading experts on Global Public Health will discuss implications of SARS-CoV-2 from a public health perspective and assess the current state of the pandemic. The discussion explains how this crisis impacts public health protocols both locally and nationally, emphasizes how small actions such as social distancing and masking result in mitigation of the viral spread, and evaluates future projections of the pandemic on a global scale. Presenters: Cheryl Anderson, PhD, MPH, Founding Dean of the University of California San Diego Herbert Wertheim School of Public Health and Human Longevity Science Ashish K. Jha, MD, MPH, Faculty Director, Harvard Global Health Institute and Professor of Medicine, Harvard Medical School Introduction: Christopher Kane, MD, Chief Executive Officer, UC San Diego Health Physician Group Christopher Longhurst, MD, Associate Chief Medical Officer and Professor of Medicine, UC San Diego Health Robert “Chip” Schooley, MD, Professor of Medicine, Division of Infectious Disease, University of California San Diego Presentation: 00:03:17 Geographic Heterogeneity in COVID-19 Mortality: 00:05:27 Forecasted SARS-CoV-2 related hospitalizations: 00:08:36 Upstream Social Factors that Impact Health: 00:11:17 The Impact of Social Distancing Interventions: 00:14:54 State of the Pandemic, Globally: 00:17:56 State of the Pandemic in the United States: 00:22:38 Future Projections: 00:26:15 Q&A – How Technology will Augment Support Efforts: 00:29:08 Q&A – What are the Benefits of Public Health Measures: 00:36:29 Q&A – How do we Deal with Fatigue at a National Level: 00:40:38 Q&A – Are the National Protests Making an Impact on the Spread of the Virus: 00:50:59 To view previously recorded and learn more about upcoming videos from the UC San Diego Health COVID-19 Virtual Grand Rounds, visit https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/Grand-Rounds.aspx. Please note, the live Menti Question and Answer code will not be active for past videos.

videoTitle: Meet T. Mike Hsieh, MD: Director, Men's Health Center
videoDescription: More about Dr. Hsieh: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/12156/urology-infertility T. Mike Hsieh, MD, is a board-certified urologist specializing in male fertility and men’s health. He treats men with sexual dysfunction including low testosterone, erectile dysfunction, and Peyronie's disease. He also treats male infertility including men with ejaculatory disorder, hormone imbalance, sperm production impairment, cancer, and genetic causes of infertility. Dr. Hseih says he has dedicated his career in helping couples conceive and helping men age well. As director of the Men's Health Center at UC San Diego Health, Dr. Hsieh's practice also includes general urology for men with kidney stones, and treating conditions such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH); elevated PSA; enlarged PSA; male urinary retention; male urinary tract infections; any masses for prostate, bladder, testis, kidney; and testicular pain. More about related specialty programs at UC San Diego Health: Urology: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/urology/Pages/default.aspx Male Fertility & Sexual Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/urology/male-reproductive-sexual-health/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Research in the COVID Pandemic: Navigating the Gap from Anecdotes to Evidenced Based Decisions
videoDescription: During times of crisis and uncertainty, it can be difficult and overwhelming to sort fact from fiction. In response, physicians at UC San Diego Health have launched the COVID-19 Virtual Grand Rounds Series, a six-part live video symposium that will focus on topics related to the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. Part One – Research in the COVID Pandemic: Navigating the Gap from Anecdotes to Evidenced-Based Decisions (July 22, 2020): Judith Currier, MD, Professor of Medicine and Chief, Division of Infectious Diseases, University of California Los Angeles, discusses the unprecedented scientific response to SARS-CoV-2, and how clinical and translational research play a vital role. Currier highlights the pathogenesis of the disease, challenges in designing and implementing clinical trials for medications to treat a new virus, progress to date, lessons learned, and vaccine development. videoTitle: Meet Joseph A. Califano, III, MD: Head and Neck Surgeon
videoDescription: Joseph A. Califano, III, MD, is a board-certified otolaryngologist who specializes in head and neck surgical oncology at UC San Diego Health. His expertise includes minimally invasive treatment of tumors of the oral cavity, larynx, pharynx, thyroid, and neck to minimize cosmetic impact and maximize function, with an interest in tumors of the skull base, mouth, salivary glands, and premalignant conditions of the upper aerodigestive tract. In this video, Dr. Califano discusses his passion for taking care of patients and families and the many benefits of receiving treatment at UC San Diego Health. Learn more about head and neck cancer care at the region's only federally recognized comprehensive cancer center: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/head-neck/Pages/default.aspx. videoTitle: Meet Jason Sicklick, MD, FACS: Surgical Oncologist
videoDescription: Learn more about Dr. Sicklick's clinical and research expertise: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11865/surgery-cancer Jason Sicklick, MD, is a surgical oncologist who specializes in treating hepatobiliary diseases and sarcomas, including gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). He has a special interest in abdominal and retroperitoneal sarcomas, primary liver tumors and colorectal and neuroendocrine cancers that have metastasized to the liver. He is part of UC San Diego Health’s Liver Cancer Clinic, which uses the most advanced, multidisciplinary approaches to treat all types of adult primary liver cancer. In this video, Dr. Sicklick explains why people with cancer, particularly those newly diagnosed with cancer, should consider coming to UC San Diego Health for evaluation and treatment. videoTitle: Man Needing Donor Heart Gets Married in Hospital | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: David Reynoso is waiting for a donor heart and transplant surgery. He has been receiving care at the Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center at UC San Diego Health for the past six weeks. Reynoso decided there's no better time than to get married to Vicky, his girlfriend of 11 years. With some exceptions, the team at the cardiovascular center helped make it happen. The couple married 11 years to the date from when they met. Congratulations David and Vicky! Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center is the region's first academic-based facility to combine all heart and vascular-related services, programs and technology under one roof. The technologies, techniques and treatments we develop at UC San Diego Health are setting new standards in vascular and cardiac care — for our patients and for the world. Learn more about the services the center is a global leader in, visit: https://healthlocations.ucsd.edu/la-jolla/9434-medical-center-drive Our center is a national hub of clinical expertise and research, and the region's leader in transplantation. Since 1968, our team has performed thousands of transplants under a national standard model of care. See the comprehensive services our team delivers, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/transplant/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: How Long Are You Contagious with COVID-19? | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: How long is COVID19 contagious? And what should you do if you think you’ve been exposed? In this video, learn more about the CDC recommendations on self-isolation following possible COVID-19 exposure or symptoms. All patients should follow their doctor’s recommendations for accessing care and leaving isolation. If you feel sick, unless it’s an emergency, try to call ahead so the doctor can direct you to the right place for care and possible testing. This video was filmed on April 16, 2020. As doctors and scientists work quickly to figure out the best ways to fight COVID19, this information may become out of date. For the most up to date information and recommendations, please visit the CDC’s website, http://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus UC San Diego Health was the first health system in the region to treat patients with COVID-19. Like hospital systems elsewhere, we have seen an increase in patients who are in need of specialized care during the COVID-19 (novel coronavirus) pandemic. We are caring for these patients at our Hillcrest and La Jolla locations in San Diego County and are well-prepared to treat more as needed. And we are embracing new ways, including telehealth, to continue seeing our other patients to keep them healthy. Get updates for UC San Diego Health patients and visitors here: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/default.aspx Other Resources: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/disposition-in-home-patients.html https://www.nfid.org/infectious-diseases/frequently-asked-questions-about-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov/ https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html

videoTitle: Meet Carie Montesa, MSN, RN: Survivorship Nurse Practitioner
videoDescription: More about Carie Montesa: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33145/cancer Carie Montesa, MSN, is a board-certified adult gerontology acute-care nurse practitioner (AGACNP-BC) who works collaboratively with the head and neck cancer team at Moores Cancer Center. This multidisciplinary team provides integrative care and cutting edge therapies such as robotic surgeries, systemic therapy, immunology, precision medicine as well as clinical trials. As part of the head and neck cancer team, Ms. Montesa specializes in survivorship care for people at all stages of their cancer journey. She focuses on quality of life care by making sure patients are not having side effects from treatment, as well as providing appropriate resources to ensure the best healthy life possible after cancer treatment. videoTitle: Meet Tiffany Tanaka, MD: Hematologist
videoDescription: More about Dr. Tanaka: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32756/blood-marrow-transplant-bmt-cancer Tiffany Tanaka, MD, is a board-certified hematologist who specializes in the diagnosis and treatment of blood cancers and blood disorders at UC San Diego Health. In this video, she discusses her decision to specialize in this field as it relates to patient care, her lab's translational research to guide treatment plans and the benefits to receiving care at an academic health system. Dr. Tanaka was drawn to hematology, a data-driven field, since it would allow her follow patients longitudinally and take care of them for a very long time. Her goal is to make sure her patients understand what their disease means and to help them set expectations about treatments. Dr. Tanaka's research focuses on the study of myeloid neoplasms, or different cancers of myeloid blood cells. Her lab's goal is determining different ways how blood diseases progress and matching them with best treatments available to patients. As an academic health system, patients have options at UC San Diego Health that might not be available at a smaller center. They have access to novel treatments and clinical trial specialists, and benefit from physicians who work collaboratively with one another to provide the best care. Hematology / Blood Disorders at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/blood-disorders/Pages/default.aspx https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/hematologic/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: What It's Like to Survive COVID-19 | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Many people who experience novel coronavirus (COVID-19) have mild symptoms. Unfortunately, that wasn't the case for Steve Padilla, who contracted the virus in March and was intubated for 11 days. Padilla, a 52-year-old city councilman for Chula Vista, describes his experience surviving COVID-19 and how the teams at UC San Diego Health helped save his life. His daughter, Ashleigh Padilla, also shares what it was like to have her father in an intensive care unit and not be able to visit him. Both father and daughter warn that this virus is a very real disease that shouldn't be taken lightly. UC San Diego Health hospitals and clinics are prepared to keep you and your family safe and healthy in these uncertain times of the novel coronavirus crisis. Here are some of the steps we have taken to protect and care for you and the community: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/safety-measures.aspx Find the latest visitor restrictions for our hospitals, emergency department and clinics at: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Pregnant Woman With COVID-19 Successfully Delivers Baby While in Coma
videoDescription: Blanca, a young pregnant mother, was admitted to the intensive care unit at UC San Diego Health in late March after testing positive for COVID-19. She could barely breathe and needed to be intubated. Her life-threatening condition required a multi-disciplinary medical team to deliver her baby via emergency cesarean section. When Blanca awoke nearly a month later, she learned she had delivered her daughter. Blanca and her baby were discharged last week and are spending Mother’s Day together. Pregnancy and childbirth can be a time of great joy as well as apprehension, especially during this time of COVID-19. We want to assure you that we are taking every precaution to ensure your safety and well-being. Learn more about maternity care and the steps designed to keep you, your family, and our providers healthy and safe: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/pregnancy-birth/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Celebrate Coronavirus Survivors: Chime Plays In Hospital When Patients with COVID-19 are Discharged
videoDescription: When a patient recovers from COVID-19 and leaves the intensive care unit at UC San Diego Health, a chime plays throughout the hospital while staff line the hallways and cheer. Patient Juan Valdez Cazares was recently greeted by the chime during his discharge, after spending several days intubated in the intensive care unit (ICU). Missy Meehan, RN, and a group of friends wrote the original melody, intended as a joyous instrumental ode to the rhythm of breathing and return to wellness. Learn more about COVID-19 resources at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: 7 Tips for Managing Cabin Fever During Coronavirus Crisis
videoDescription: While our abilities to go to work and school, gather with friends and loved ones and participate in other social activities outside the home are restricted, some of us may find ourselves experiencing cabin fever. Cabin fever isn’t a real medical diagnosis, but experiencing negative emotions, restlessness, irritability and boredom associated with restricted movement and confinement can feel real enough. Jamie M. Gannon, PhD, clinical psychologist at UC San Diego Health, offers seven tips to ease emotional strain during this difficult time. Read more about cabin fever and coronavirus: https://ucsdhealthsciences.tumblr.com/post/614402527232983040/tips-for-fighting-cabin-fever-during-coronavirus See the latest information from UC San Diego Health regarding COVID-19: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus

videoTitle: San Diego Family Paints 'Love Rocks' To Support UC San Diego Health Staff
videoDescription: Inspired by the memory of when a loved one fell ill, the Fitzpatrick family of San Diego coordinated with leaders at UC San Diego Health to drop off a special delivery for staff currently facing the novel coronavirus crisis. They donated more than 150 rocks adorned with uplifting messages. Times like these bring us together and we're so grateful for our community's support. For more information on how to donate items, including protective equipment, supplies and other items, please visit health.ucsd.edu/covid-donate. The office of Experience Transformation at UC San Diego Health is also pleased to coordinate community expressions of gratitude in the form of letters, cards, notes or drawings to share and display for our health care team members. videoTitle: 5 Tips to Protect Your Mental Health During Coronavirus Crisis | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: In the face of uncertainty, managing anxiety and stress while also staying prepared and informed can be difficult. So what can you do to protect your mental health as the COVID-19 outbreak unfolds? Here are some recommendations from the experts. Put down the smart phone. Take breaks from social media and the news. Give your mind a chance to disconnect. Consider setting up specific times or time limits on how long you spend checking the news each day, so you can stay informed without getting overwhelmed. Take care of yourself. Engage in healthy habits as much as possible. Eat well-balanced meals, get some exercise, get plenty of sleep, and avoid bad habits, like too much alcohol. Enjoy your hobbies. Take the time to engage in relaxing activities, like reading a book, cooking a nice meal, or doing something creative like painting or knitting. Check in with your friends and family. Social distancing doesn’t mean social isolation! Connect with the people you care about to share your concerns and feelings and see how you can help support them. Take a deep breath to avoid burnout. If you’re feeling overwhelmed, stop and take a deep breath. Step back and give yourself space to process your feelings. Consider doing some stretches or yoga, or engaging in a short mindfulness exercise to help keep you grounded. If your stress is interfering with your daily life, contact your health care provider to ask about additional care and resources. One place you can visit: UC San Diego Health – Psychiatry and Behavioral Health at: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/behavioral-mental-health/Pages/default.aspx The Center For Mindfulness, The Sanford Institute, and the Compassion Institute at UC San Diego Health are working together to provide daily resources to support mindfulness and compassion. Find their schedule and resources here: https://cih.ucsd.edu/mindfulness/free-sessions For the latest information for UC San Diego Health patients and visitors, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/coronavirus

videoTitle: Meet Frederic Kolb, MD, Plastic Surgeon
videoDescription: More about Dr. Kolb: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/33234/plastic-surgery-cancer Frederic Kolb, MD, is an internationally recognized board-certified plastic surgeon who specializes in oncologic reconstruction, correcting defects following breast, head and neck, skin, and soft tissue and sarcoma resections. Dr. Kolb’s expertise includes supramicrosurgery, a field of plastic surgery performed on vessels smaller than 0.5 mm in diameter. This can be an option for patients with lymphedema (extreme swelling in arms or legs). He also performs vascularized nerve grafts to treat patients with nerve injuries. Dr. Kolb developed this technique for reanimation in facial palsy. Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/plastic-reconstructive-surgery Cancer Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: What It's Like to Be an Adult with a Congenital Heart Defect
videoDescription: Cristi Walker has been living with congenital heart disease — in essence, half of a functional heart. Her condition, called pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum, required multiple surgeries throughout childhood. Now Walker, 32, requires specialized adult cardiac care to address her complex health needs. She has become a patient of the Adult Congenital Heart Disease Program at UC San Diego Health. Hear her candid and powerful story about what it is like to be an adult with congenital heart disease. More about adult Adult Congenital Heart Disease Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cardiovascular/programs/congenital-heart-disease/pages/default.aspx More about Dr. Alshawabkeh: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32899/laith-alshawabkeh #WhatItsLike #AskTheRightQuestions #CHD #CongenitalHeartDisease

videoDescription: UC San Diego Health illuminated the Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center in La Jolla red during American Heart Month in February 2020. We do it to raise awareness of heart disease and stroke, and improve women's health in our communities. "We’re making a difference! A big thank you to everyone who helped us kick off American Heart Month. We’re proud to be a longtime participant in this national movement to end heart disease and stroke in women. Wishing everyone a strong and healthy heart,” said Patty Maysent, CEO. Help us prevent heart disease and stroke, and improve women’s health. videoTitle: Medical Pioneer: First Patient Receives Unique Rare Disease Therapy Developed at UC San Diego
videoDescription: Born with a rare disease called cystinosis, at age 20 Jordan Janz faced a difficult decision: continue as is, toward a future that most likely involves kidney failure and an early death, or take a leap of faith and become the first patient to receive a unique gene-and-stem cell therapy, developed over more than a decade of research at UC San Diego School of Medicine. videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Helps San Diego Zoo Safari Park Save 3-year-old Gorilla’s Eyesight
videoDescription: Animal care specialists at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park noticed cloudiness in the left eye of Leslie, a 3-year-old female western lowland gorilla. Closer inspection confirmed the lens had changed and the left eye was shifting haphazardly, prompting Leslie to favor use of her right eye. Safari Park veterinarians organized a team of internal and external experts, including UC San Diego Health anesthesiologists and an ophthalmology team led by Chris Heichel, MD, cataract surgery specialist at Shiley Eye Institute at UC San Diego Health and professor of ophthalmology in the Viterbi Family Department of Ophthalmology at UC San Diego School of Medicine, to perform the Park’s first-ever cataract surgery on a gorilla. More about Dr. Heichel: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11523/ophthalmology More about Shiley Eye Institute at UC San Diego Health: https://shileyeye.ucsd.edu/

videoTitle: What It’s Like to be an Amputee Wearing A Prosthetic Leg | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: After having her leg amputated at 16 years old, Danielle McLaughlin has gone on to run marathons and empower other people living with a disability. Danielle was diagnosed with synovial sarcoma, a rare form of cancer that occurs in the extremities of the arms or legs, and it resulted in the amputation of her leg below her left knee. Hear what she has to say about what it is like to be an amputee wearing a prosthetic leg. UC San Diego Health has played a big part in Danielle’s life. As a patient, she has built a strong relationship with physicians, nurses and staff in primary care, orthopedics and at the cancer center. On top of being a patient, Danielle said she feels fortunate to also work for the health system as the physician group governance director. Learn more about our orthopedic oncology program https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/sarcoma/Pages/default.aspx #WhatItsLike #AskTheRightQuestions #Amputee

videoTitle: Why We Movember | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Many men who work at UC San Diego Health grew facial hair in November to bring awareness to men’s health issues. The Movember movement is committed to saving men’s lives by discussing prostate cancer, testicular cancer, mental health and suicide prevention. “Not shaving during November is a great way to generate awareness and start conversations around the many types of cancers often experienced by men,” said Will Sutherland, senior director of primary care at UC San Diego Health. “My family has been touched by all types of cancer and therefore having (what some would call a beard) on my face is a daily reminder of those who are impacted by this devastating disease.” At UC San Diego Health, we understand the unique needs of our male patients of all ages. To learn more about the services provided for men, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/Pages/default.aspx #Movember #Movember2019

videoTitle: Parkinson and Other Movement Disorders Center at UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: Movement disorders are neurological conditions that affect the speed, control, quality and ease of movement. UC San Diego Health is dedicated to providing the best diagnosis, therapeutic, palliative and supportive care to patients with movement disorders and related neurodegenerative diseases. At The Parkinson and Other Movement Disorders Center, our main objective is to improve the quality of life for our patients and their families and caregivers, while searching for significant ways to advance knowledge of these disorders through a multidisciplinary clinical and research team. Disciplines such as physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, neuropsychology, and neurology, all work together to provide the best in patient care. More about our care for Parkinson disease and other movement disorders: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/neuro/specialty-programs/movement-disorders/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Recovering from an Eating Disorder as an Athlete
videoDescription: Kamila Tan, a beach volleyball player, shares her experience of being an athlete with an eating disorder and how the Eating Disorders Treatment and Research Program at UC San Diego helped her recover and return to her sport. UC San Diego Health's Eating Disorders Treatment and Research Program is an international leader in eating disorder treatment and research. Using genetics and brain imaging to further understand the causes of all types of eating disorders, they are able to develop therapies that can help effectively treat patients with disorders including binge-eating disorder, atypical anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. Their multidisciplinary team includes highly skilled and dedicated psychologists, psychiatrists and dietitians who are able to treat severely ill patients who may otherwise need an inpatient program. Learn more about the Eating Disorders Treatment and Research Program at UCSD: http://eatingdisorders.ucsd.edu

videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Honor Walk Pays Tribute to Fire Captain
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health, in partnership with Lifesharing, conducted its first Honor Walk to pay tribute to a fire captain who selflessly donated his organs. Four of Robin Cervantes' organs saved the lives of four patients. The walks provide family members with an opportunity to accompany their loved one to the operating room before organ donation is made and to share a few final moments. Medical team members line the hallways to support the family and recognize the precious gift of donation. Each Honor Walk is signaled by a beautiful chime composed by a nurse at UC San Diego Health and a Donate Life flag is raised in front of the hospital to let the community know that an Honor Walk has taken place. Learn more about our transplant services and how to become a donor like Robin: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/transplant-programs/organ-tissue-donation/

videoTitle: Space Organoid Study: Microgravity on Human Brain Development
videoDescription: Alysson Muotri, PhD, director of the Stem Cell Program at UC San Diego, is leading an experiment to study the impact of microgravity on human brain development, research which could improve disease modeling for neurodegenerative and developmental disorders as well as give clues into the future of humanity in space. Muotri has developed brain organoids from stem cells to be launched into space on a Space X rocket on July 21. The organoids will spend 4 weeks onboard the ISS before returning to Earth for evaluation. More about Dr. Muotri’s research: https://medschool.ucsd.edu/som/pediatrics/research/labs/muotri-lab/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Ringing the Bell Signifies End of Cancer Treatment
videoDescription: In honor of National Cancer Survivors Day, we reflect on the day Michelle Brubaker rang the bell in Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health. It signified she had completed chemotherapy treatments. Months later, Michelle transitioned from patient to survivorship and beyond. “I looked at that bell after each round of chemo. It gave me the strength to get through my 10 sessions," Michelle said today looking back at the experience. "I had a lot of mixed emotions when I was finally able to ring it. That bell had deep meaning. It was a huge chapter closed and the beginning of a new beautiful one.” More about Cancer Services at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/Pages/default.aspx
tags: San Diego,Cancer Survivors,Cancer,Chemotherapy,Hospital,Medical,UC San Diego Health,health care,Breast Cancer
caption: true

videoTitle: Kids Sew Pillows with Messages of Hope for Patients with Cancer
videoDescription: When Alexis, Jonah, Sasha and Isabel found out a beloved family member would be undergoing cancer treatment at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health they handmade a pillow to keep him comfortable during his treatment sessions. “We knew this would mean lots of doctor appointments and time away from home. It was important to us to help our family member feel like we were always with him, and so he could feel our love at all times.” Inside the pillow, the children hid handwritten thoughts of love, hope and good wishes. This one small pillow turned into much more – it turned into project “Stuffed with Love.” The kids sewed more than 100 pillows and delivered them to Moores Cancer Center to share with other people undergoing cancer treatment.

videoTitle: Know the Signs of a Stroke - BE FAST
videoDescription: May is Stroke Awareness Month so it's a good time to learn about the signs of a possible stroke using the BEFAST method to identify new symptoms or changes in: Balance, Eyes/vision, Face (changes in symmetry), Arm and leg weakness, and Speech. Time is of the essence so seek medical attention right away if you have any of these stroke warning signs. UC San Diego Health treats the most complex stroke cases at our two Comprehensive Stroke Centers in Hillcrest and La Jolla. More about Stroke Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/stroke/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Nurse Becomes the Patient and Goes Red for Heart Health
videoDescription: One day, while Laura Holcomb, nurse manager, was walking into work at the Cardiovascular Institute at UC San Diego Health, she felt something in her chest pop and her heart start to race. “I felt like I was having a massive heart attack.” UC San Diego Health doctors discovered a congenital heart defect and performed open heart surgery to save her life. Millions of Americans like Holcomb suffer from heart disease, which kills more women each year than all cancers combined. Her story illustrates the need to bring awareness to heart disease, symptoms and prevention. That's why UC San Diego Health joins with the American Heart Association to promote their Go Red for Women campaign in February, which is women's heart health month. Learn more about cardiac care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cardiovascular/Pages/default.aspx
tags: Laura Holcomb,Go Red for Women,UCSD Cardiology,UC San Diego Health Cardiology,Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center,Heart Health Month,heart attack San Diego,AHA,go red,womens heart health
caption: true

videoTitle: Makayla's Sound-Saving Surgery for NF2: Auditory Brainstem Implant Safeguards Hearing
videoDescription: Makayla Christenson was diagnosed with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), a rare genetic disorder that is characterized by the growth of noncancerous tumors of the nervous system. Almost all NF2 patients develop bilateral acoustic neuroma tumors (vestibular schwannomas) on the auditory nerves, which often leaves them with hearing loss in both ears. Fortunately, she was a candidate for an auditory brainstem implant (ABI), which will prevent her from living in total deafness. Learn about Makayla and her family’s journey to UC San Diego Health, where they partnered with a care team that gave them hope after her diagnosis. Learn more about neurofibromatosis type 2 at: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/otolaryngology/areas-expertise/acoustic-neuroma/pages/nf2.aspx Learn more about Dr. Rick Friedman at: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32904/ent-head-and-neck-(otolaryngology)-surgery Learn more about Dr. Marc Schwartz at: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32903/neurosurgery-cancer 0:00 Intro Video 0:02 Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2) Diagnosis 0:43 Auditory Brainstem Implant Option 1:06 Finding Acoustic Neuroma Program 2:10 Acoustic Neuroma Program Benefits 2:45 Why Choose UC San Diego Health 3:35 Life After Acoustic Neuroma Surgery

videoTitle: Planning for the Unexpected: How and Why to Prepare an Advance Directive
videoDescription: If you become ill or injured and unable to make decisions for yourself, advance care planning gives your family or other advocates the tools they need to act on your behalf. An advance directive is a document that names your surrogate decision maker and the medical interventions that you would want. In this video, UC San Diego Health’s nursing team talks about how to put an advance care plan in place. For more information about Advance Care Planning: https://health.ucsd.edu/patients/yourhospitalstay/pages/directives.aspx

videoTitle: Breast Cancer: Facing the Next Day
videoDescription: "Is there a loved one in the waiting room?" Michelle knew what would come next but she couldn't even say the word "cancer." She's too young. What about her boys? Michelle documented every stage of her breast cancer treatment at UC San Diego Health, complete with raw emotions and the trials that come with it. Her doctors, Anne Wallace, Richard Schwab and James Urbanic, help explain the process along the way. To learn more about breast cancer treatment at Moores Cancer Center, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/breast/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Join All of Us in California
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health is proud to participate in the All of Us Research Program. The goal is to help researchers understand more about why people get sick or stay healthy. In California, this effort is being implemented by the California Precision Medicine Consortium, which is led by Lucila Ohno-Machado at UC San Diego Health and Hoda Anton-Culver at UC Irvine. We hope that more than one million people nationwide will join All of Us. People who join will partner with us to provide information about their health, habits and what it’s like where they live. By looking for patterns in all this data, researchers may learn more about what affects people’s health and may find ways to better tailor treatments to individuals—something we call “precision medicine.” To learn more, please visit: https://joinallofus.org
tags: research,All of Us,precision medicine,personalized medicine,NIH,diversity
caption: true

videoTitle: Having a Baby at UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: UC San Diego Health's hospitals in La Jolla and Hillcrest offer more childbirth options than anywhere else in San Diego. With two distinct birth settings -- spacious Labor and Delivery rooms and a Birth Center staffed with certified nurse midwives -- we are committed to honoring your childbirth choices and making your pregnancy and childbirth a special experience. Also available are volunteer doulas, a world-class Level III Neonatal Intensive Care Unit, state-of-the-art surgical suites for cesarean deliveries, and world-renowned lactation experts. videoTitle: Silent No More: Tongue Cancer Surgery and Rehabilitation Restore a Voice
videoDescription: For three months, Cynthia Zamora was left speechless after a team of surgeons removed a tumor that took up more than half of her tongue. To save her life, a multidisciplinary team of head and neck cancer experts at UC San Diego Health, led by Joseph A. Califano, MD, designed a comprehensive plan to: eradicate an aggressive squamous cell carcinoma; create a new tongue using tissue from her thigh; and teach her how to speak, eat and walk again. Today, Zamora speaks slowly with a raspy voice, but she is thankful that she has a voice and can eat fried chicken again. Learn more about head and neck cancer treatment at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/head-neck/Pages/default.aspx More about Dr. Califano: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/32523/ent-head-and-neck-(otolaryngology)-cancer
tags: tongue cancer,head and neck cancer,UC San Diego Health,Moores Cancer Center,squamous cell carcinoma,Joseph Califano MD,Dr. Joseph A. Califano,Liza S. Blumenfeld,Liza Blumenfeld,tongue reconstruction,speech language pathology,speech therapy,speech rehabilitation
caption: false

videoTitle: Powered by Chemo: Patient with Pancreatic Cancer Tackles Ironman
videoDescription: Despite a diagnosis of stage IV pancreatic cancer and ongoing chemotherapy, Mike Levine will compete in one of the most grueling of physical competitions: the Ironman World Championship. When Mike's cancer spread to his lungs he began end-of-life planning but a second opinion at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health gave him one more chance to compete in the sport he loves. For more on chemotherapy at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/infusion/Pages/default.aspx UPDATE: After four years of living with pancreatic cancer, Mike succumbed to the disease in January 2020. We thank him and his family for allowing us to share his inspiring story.
tags: Cancer,Health,UC San Diego,Medicine,UCSD,pancreatic cancer,Ironman,Triathlon,Sports,Run,Swim,Cycling,UC San Diego Health,Moores Cancer Center
caption: true

videoTitle: Turning a Phage: Innovative Therapy Clears Infection and Allows Heart Transplantion
videoDescription: Joel Grimwood needed a new heart, but a chronic bacterial infection lurking within his implanted ventricle assist device made getting one impossible. Five transplant centers declined his case due to his persistent infection. Then Grimwood came to UC San Diego Health, where doctors treated the infection with an experimental bacteriophage therapy – viruses that eat bacteria. The infection cleared and Grimwood got his new heart. For more about phage therapy at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/infectious-disease/pages/default.aspx
tags: bacteriophage therapy,UC San Diego Health,nonischemic cardiomyopathy,left ventricle assist device,LVAD,Dr. Saima Aslam,Saima Aslam MD,heart transplant,device infection,hepatitis C organ transplantation,phage therapy
caption: true

videoTitle: A Soldier's Story: Advanced Heart Failure and Transplant Care
videoDescription: At the age of 24, Sean Dobbs was diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy — a condition in which the heart becomes enlarged and cannot pump blood effectively. He later developed end-stage heart failure and needed a heart transplant. UC San Diego Health cardiologist Eric David Adler, MD, implanted a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) that allowed Sean to regain his health as he awaited a donor heart. Cardiothoracic surgeon Victor Pretorius, MBChB, led the transplant team that performed Sean’s lifesaving surgery. More about ventricular assist devices at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/heart-vascular/heart-failure/vad/ More about heart transplantation at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/transplant-programs/heart
tags: UC San Diego Health,UC San Diego Cardiovascular Institute,dilated cardiomyopathy,left ventricular assist device,LVAD,heart transplant,Dr. Eric David Adler,Eric David Adler MD,Dr. Victor Pretorius,Victor Pretorius MBChB,Jacobs Medical Center
caption: true

videoTitle: Head and Neck Cancer Awareness: Overview of Risk Factors, Screening, Types and Treatments
videoDescription: Nearly 50,000 new cases of head and neck cancers were diagnosed in 2017. The incidence of this disease has been slowly rising over the past decade. For head and neck cancer awareness week April 8-15, Joseph Califano, MD, director of the head and neck cancer center at UC San Diego Health defines head and neck cancer and treatment options. Ezra Cohen, MD, Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health oncologist, explains risk factors including smoking and HPV, as well as screening and prevention. Learn more about head and neck cancer at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/programs/head-neck/Pages/default.aspx
