videoTitle: Like Father, Like Daughter: Acoustic Neuroma Microsurgery Saves Patient's Hearing
videoDescription: When Melissa De La O was diagnosed with an acoustic neuroma, a rare, non-cancerous brain tumor that often times leaves patients with hearing loss, she knew what she was up against. Thirty years earlier, the same type of tumor rendered her father partially deaf. Learn how this father-daughter duo experienced an emotional journey together, including the moment when De La O awoke from surgery to discover she could still hear. Learn more about acoustic neuroma microsurgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/otolaryngology/areas-expertise/acoustic-neuroma/Pages/default.aspx 0:00 Intro Video 0:20 Family History of Acoustic Neuroma 0:36 What is an Acoustic Neuroma? 1:14 Risks of Acoustic Neuroma Surgery 1:31 Goal of Acoustic Neuroma Surgery 1:56 Patient-Centered Care

videoTitle: Unborn Baby Saved After Second Opinion for Cancer Care | UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: After several years of trying, the Ingram family was going to have a new addition. But just as Leigh Ingram started her second trimester, she got more life-changing news: a diagnosis of stage IV tonsil cancer. To save her life, Leigh was advised to terminate the pregnancy. A second opinion at UC San Diego Health provided other options. Today, Leigh is healthy with a happy six-month-old daughter named Layne. To learn more about second opinions options at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cancer/second-opinion/pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: How to Stop the Bleed
videoDescription: A person can die from blood loss within five minutes. It's often the nearest bystander who has the best chance of saving that person's life. Stop the Bleed is a national awareness campaign to train and equip bystanders to respond before professional help arrives. Trauma surgeon Jay Doucet, MD, FACS, demonstrates how best to "stop the bleed" in three different scenarios: 1) when you have nothing, 2) when you have a Stop the Bleed kit or tourniquet, or 3) when you can’t put a tourniquet on the wound but you have gauze. Always remember to make sure you are safe and call 911 before helping someone else. For more information, visit: www.dhs.gov/stopthebleed More about UC San Diego Health emergency care https://health.ucsd.edu/care/walk-in-same-day/#emergency-care 0:00 Stop The Bleed 0:20 Using Direct Pressure 0:59 Trauma Kit 1:40 Applying A Tourniquet 3:06 Wound Packing 3:51 Positioning The Patient Please note that Dr. Doucet, featured in this video, is a former employee of UC San Diego Health. The information he shares in this video remains current and valuable to viewers.

videoTitle: Inside Look of a Cardiac Hybrid Operating Room
videoDescription: A pacemaker or implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) deliver energy to your heart muscle through wires called leads. A lead extraction is when one or more of those are removed. UC San Diego does more lead extractions each year than any other facility in the region, having performed more than 450. The procedure is done in a “hybrid” operating room, with both state-of-the-art imaging equipment and everything necessary for open heart surgery. videoTitle: Autism Spectrum Disorder: The Cell Danger Response
videoDescription: A small, randomized clinical trial at UC San Diego School of Medicine found that a single intravenous dose of a century-old drug called suramin produced measurable, but transient, improvement of core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). But more broadly, the trial findings support the “Cell Danger Response theory,” which posits that autism and other chronic conditions are fundamentally driven by metabolic dysfunction—and thus treatable. This whiteboard animation explains Cell Danger Response in autistic neurons before and after suramin treatment. More about UC San Diego Autism Center of Excellence: https://neurosciences.ucsd.edu/centers-programs/autism/index.html
tags: UC San Diego Health,autism,suramin,cell danger response,autism spectrum disorder San Diego,San Diego autism treatment,treatment for autism
caption: false

videoTitle: Century-Old Drug Tested in Boys with Autism
videoDescription: Suramin is a 100-year-old drug developed to treat African sleeping sickness. It is not approved for any therapeutic use in the U.S. However, a small clinical trial at UC San Diego School of Medicine found that a single intravenous dose of suramin produced measurable, but transient, improvements in five boys with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). More broadly, the trial findings support the “cell danger response theory,” which posits that autism is driven by metabolic dysfunction — and thus treatable. Larger, longer clinical trials are needed to assess suramin as an ASD treatment. In this video, we hear from lead researcher Robert Naviaux, MD, PhD, and the mothers of two boys who received suramin in the trial. For more information about Autism, visit: https://health.ucsd.edu/care/neurological/autism/
tags: science,health,medicine,UC San Diego Health,autism,suramin,clinical trial
caption: false

videoTitle: Couple Marries in Their Final Moments at UC San Diego Health
videoDescription: After being together for nearly nine years, Stanley and Ana got married surrounded by their family and friends. But instead of a chapel, a white wedding dress and a tuxedo, the couple was saying their “I Do’s” in a room at Thornton Hospital. The bride was wearing a black dress and the groom was wearing blue scrubs. Stanley’s colon cancer had metastasized. It was terminal. See how the staff at UC San Diego Health (https://health.ucsd.edu) planned the couple’s wedding day in less than 24 hours, and the true testament to love that made Stanley and Ana so determined to form this special union in sickness and in health.

videoTitle: New Approach to Gallbladder Surgery Uses A Tiny Incision
videoDescription: Surgeons at UC San Diego Health are offering a new approach to minimally invasive gallbladder surgery. Normally, a diseased gallbladder is surgically removed with four small incisions. This new approach uses one incision, approximately half an inch in width, that is hidden in the belly button. Santiago Horgan, MD, chief of minimally invasive surgery, said the new approach is better for patients in terms of healing and appearance. He cites fewer incision site complications, less post-operative pain, reduced chance of hernia, faster recovery and exceptional cosmetic outcomes as potential benefits. Learn more about minimally invasive surgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/mis/Pages/default.aspx More about Dr. Horgan: https://providers.ucsd.edu/details/11548/weight-loss-surgery-(bariatric)-cancer

videoTitle: Type 1 Diabetes Patient Climbs to New Heights

videoTitle: Cancer Immunotherapy: Rikki Rockett's Story
videoDescription: The band Poison’s co-founder and drummer, Rikki Rockett, was diagnosed with oral cancer more than a year ago. When chemotherapy and radiation treatment failed to eradicate his cancer, Rockett came to Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health to participate in a clinical trial testing experimental cancer immunotherapy. A few months later, he received the best news of his life: his cancer is gone. In this video, he tells his story at a UC San Diego Health education event on Aug. 20, 2016. He is the clinic’s trial expert for cancer and a professor of Medicine at UC San Diego School of Medicine. videoTitle: New Surgical Approach for Obesity Requires No Incision
videoDescription: Dr. Santiago Horgan from UC San Diego Health talks to San Diego Connect about a new type of surgical approach that is minimally invasive and requires no incisions. The procedure consists of an adjustable saline balloon placed in the stomach, which encourages food portion control and has been shown to reduce total body weight by 10 percent. videoTitle: Orthopedic Surgeon Saves Emily's Leg From Amputation
videoDescription: Emily Sunderland underwent 16 surgeries on her leg before coming to UC San Diego Health, but it remained infected. She was in constant pain and on heavy medications. Desperate to get her life back, Emily was ready to have her leg amputated at the hip—a procedure so extreme she wouldn’t be able to wear a prosthetic. Then she met Dr. Anna Kulidjian, an orthopedic surgeon at UC San Diego Health, who believed she could save Emily’s leg and get her back to a normal life. Learn more about orthopedic surgery at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/ortho

videoTitle: Salt Intake and Chronic Kidney Disease
videoDescription: In this video, dietitian Christy Turner, MS, RD, at UC San Diego Health discusses the importance of limiting salt for your kidney health. Limiting your salt intake is important for achieving optimal blood pressure control. Damaged kidneys cannot filter sodium as well as healthy kidneys. As a result, sodium can stay in your body and cause your blood pressure to go up and can cause swelling. More information about Kidney Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/kidney/Pages/default.aspx

caption: false

videoTitle: Phosphorus Intake and Chronic Kidney Disease
videoDescription: In this video, dietitian Christy Turner, MD, RD, at UC San Diego Health discusses phosphorus intake in chronic kidney disease. Phosphorus is a mineral that helps keep your bones healthy and helps keep blood vessels and muscles working. When blood phosphorus levels are high, you can experience weakened bones, itchy skin, and bone and joint pain. Learn more about Kidney Care at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/kidney/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: Chronic Kidney Disease: Potassium Intake
videoDescription: In this video nutritionist Christy Turner, MS, RD, at UC San Diego Health discusses potassium intake in chronic kidney disease. Your kidneys may not be able to remove enough potassium from your blood which can be dangerous; this is usually not seen until more advanced kidney disease. videoTitle: UC San Diego Cardiology Team Performs 100th Extraction Procedure with 100 Percent Success Rate
videoDescription: A multidisciplinary team from the Sulpizio Cardiovascular Center at University of California San Diego Health System has performed its 100th lead (pronounced 'leed') extraction surgery, a delicate procedure to replace the thin wiring of lifesaving heart devices such as pacemakers or implantable defibrillators (ICDs). The collaborative program, pioneered at UC San Diego Health System, has a 100 percent success rate. Pacemakers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) deliver energy to the heart through thin, flexible wires or "leads." When these leads are not working properly -- due to infection, damage, or scar tissue -- the wires need to be removed and replaced. In particular, old leads can shift over extended periods of time and become improperly attached to the heart and blood vessel walls, and in need of repair. Each year, about 700,000 new heart devices are implanted into patients worldwide, involving about 1.4 million lead wires. When needed, the leads can be removed using a minimally invasive procedure called "lead extraction." The leads are accessed through a small incision at the site of the device, just above the heart. The surgeon slides a tube or sheath with a long wire inside the vein and over the lead that needs to be removed. This forms a stable platform for removal. Using X-ray guidance, the surgeon then applies laser energy to dissolve the scar tissue around the lead. This allows the lead to be freed from the blood vessel wall and eventually from its attachment inside the heart. Once the old lead has been removed it can be replaced with a new one. The 100th patient, JenyLyn Carpio, was 22 years old when she experienced a total heart blockage and was diagnosed with a genetic heart disorder that makes her prone to sudden death events. Learn more about the Cardiovascular Institute at UC San Diego: https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/cardiovascular/Pages/default.aspx

videoTitle: UC San Diego Health Doula Program
videoDescription: Doulas offer care and comfort for women and their families during childbirth. Using techniques such as movement, massage, breathing and relaxation, they help a mother-to-be feel safe and confident throughout her entire labor process, and will stay by her side until the baby is born. UC San Diego Health offers free volunteer doulas (subject to availability). Learn more about doula service at UC San Diego Health: https://health.ucsd.edu/doula
